property.description: The password alias of the host security password used to login to the IMS Connect server.

property.name: TranCode
property.summary: Transaction Code
property.description: The IMS transaction code to invoke.

property.name: Group
property.summary: RACF Group
property.description: The group the Host security ID belongs to.

property.name: Datastore
property.summary: Data Store of the IMS Server
property.description: It specifies the Datastore name (IMS destination ID).

property.name: ClientID
property.summary: Client ID
property.description: A string of 1 to 8 uppercase alphanumeric (A through Z, 0 to 9) or special (@, #, $) characters, left justified, and padded with blanks. The string specifies the name of the client ID that is used by IMS Connect. If this string is not supplied from the client, the user exit generates it.

property.name: LtermName
property.summary: Logical Terminal name
property.description: LTERM override value to be used by OTMA.

property.name: Exit
property.summary: Exit Identifier to use for all the IMS connections.

description.p: Specify the exit identifier to use for all the IMS connections. If no exit identifier is specified, *SAMPLE* is used.

The appliance supports the standard exit identifiers *SAMPLE* and *SAMPL1* and any identifiers that implement exits that conform to these wire protocols. If *SAMPL1*, or an identifier that conforms to *SAMPL1* wire protocol, is specified, set the Expect LLLL Response Header property to "on". Otherwise, the Expect LLLL Response Header property must be set to "off".

property.name: EBCDICConversion
property.summary: Convert headers to EBCDIC
property.description: This option can be turned on for converting the headers to EBCDIC. The IMS Connect exit should be able to process EBCDIC data. Some IMS Connect exits can handle both UTF-8 and EBCDIC. This conversion affects only the headers. Any data conversion should be done in the policy using transformation.

property.name: EncodingScheme
property.summary: Encoding scheme
property.description: Select the Unicode encoding schema. Leave as (none) to be set dynamically in the IMS header. (For example, in the IMS proxy scenario, incoming IMS header value could be used directly.)

property.name: IRMTimer
property.summary: IRM Timer values
property.description: Set the IRM_TIMER value to an appropriate wait time for IMS to return data to IMS Connect. See the IMS Connect documentation for details. An example value of 21 sets an IRM Timer value of 0.21 sec.

property.name: GenerateClientIDPrefix
property.summary: Generate Client ID Prefix
property.description: Two letter prefix for the generated client ID. "DP" is used if not specified.

property.name: MaxSegmentSize
property.summary: Maximum Segment Size
property.description: Specify "0" (OFF) or an integer in the range 1 - 32 that represents the segment size in kilobytes. The default value is 0, which disables segmentation.

property.name: ExpectLLLLHeader
property.summary: Expect 4-Byte LLLL Response Message Header
property.description: Indicates whether the response message includes an extra 4-byte LLLL header that specifies the total response message size back from IMS Connect. The default value is off.

property.name: SyncLevel
property.summary: Sync Level: 0x00 (NONE) or 0x01 (CONFIRM)

description.p: Indicates whether the Sync Level is 0x00 (NONE) or 0x01 (CONFIRM). The default value is 0x00 (NONE).

When communicating with the IMS Connect server and a transaction is specified with a Sync Level of 0x01 (CONFIRM), the client must send an ACK (successful) or a NAK (unsuccessful) after processing the response. The IMS Connect server then sends DEALLOCATE CONFIRM (successful) or DEALLOCATE ABORT (unsuccessful) back to the client.
The appliance always sends an ACK upon receiving the response and then checks for the DEALLOCATE CONFIRM.

property.name: CommitMode
property.summary: Commit Mode: 0 or 1
property.description: Commit mode 0 (CM0) is known as commit-then-send, which is the IMS standard flow. When set to 0, IMS processes the transaction and commits the data before the response is returned to the DataPower service. The default commit mode is 1.

property.name: PurgeNotDeliv
property.summary: Whether to purge or queue undeliverable transactions

description.p: Indicates whether to purge or queue undeliverable IMS transaction output that use commit mode 0. Undeliverable transaction output is when the IMS output cannot be returned to the OTMA client application that initiated the transaction. The OTMA client application is the DataPower service that initiated the original transaction. The default behavior is to queue undeliverable transaction output.

ul.li: When purge, the IRM_F3_PURGE flag is set in the IRM_F3 field. This flag with commit mode 0 configures IMS to purge transaction output when the IMS output cannot be delivered or returned to the DataPower appliance.

When queue, IMS stores undeliverable transaction output on the asynchronous hold queue. The undeliverable IMS output message remains on the IMS hold queue until you run the /DEQTMEMBER TPIPE command to clean up the queue.

object.description: IMS Connect properties. Properties on the Advanced tab are default values. Some of these properties can be overridden in the URL and others through header injection.

object.name: IncludeConfig

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: URL
property.summary: URL of Included Configuration File
property.description: Enter the URL of the configuration file to include. The file must be a configuration file of type .cfg. The URL should take the form 'protocol://username:password@host/path' if a username and password is required to retrieve the file.

property.name: OnStartup
property.summary: Execute the include on startup.
property.description: When set to 'on' the configuration is executed at startup. The configuration will be marked external and cannot be saved locally. It is equivalent to 'include-always'. When set to 'off' executing the configuration has to be executed manually. The configuration will not be marked external and can be saved locally. It is equivalent to 'include-once'.

property.name: InterfaceDetection
property.summary: Wait for operational interface.
property.description: This setting only affects the execution of configuration files from remote servers. If set to 'on' the remote file is executed asynchronously. It will be executed after the associated IP interface is operational.

object.description: Allows the inclusion of external configuration files during startup. The included configuration files may reside on the local device or on a remote host.

object.name: InteropService

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: Custom XML manager
property.description: You can specify an existing XML Manager, or create a new XML Manager and assign that XML Manager to the Interoperability Test Service instead of the default one.

property.name: AAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA Policy
property.description: Edit the AAA Policy to customize the authentication and authorization policy to Interoperability Test Service.

property.name: HttpService
property.summary: Enable the Interoperability Test Service via HTTP.
property.description: When set to enabled, the Interoperability Test Service is available via HTTP.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address
property.description: Specify the address that the service listens on. The default value "0.0.0.0" indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. See Host Alias under Networking for more information.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Port that the Interoperability Test Service listens on
property.description: Specify the port that the Interoperability Test Service listens on.

property.name: ACL
property.description: Specify an Access Control List. Access Control List is used to allow or deny access to the service based on the IP address of the client.

property.name: HttpsService
property.summary: Enable the Interoperability Test Service via HTTPS.
property.description: When set to enabled, the Interoperability Test Service is available via HTTPS.

property.name: HttpsLocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address
property.description: Specify the address that the secured service listens on. The default value "0.0.0.0" indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. See Host Alias under Networking for more information.

property.name: HttpsLocalPort
property.summary: Port that the secured Interoperability Test Service listens on
property.description: Specify the port that the secured Interoperability Test Service listens on.

property.name: HttpsACL
property.description: Specify an Access Control List. Access Control List is used to allow or deny access to the service based on the IP address of the client.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL server profile or SSL SNI server profile.
property.description: The SSL proxy profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

object.description: This page shows the configuration of the Interoperability Test Service. Interoperability Test Service is used to test stylesheets or maps. The service is available via HTTP or HTTPS, and it is disabled by default.

object.name: IPInterface

property.name: UseARP
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE - ARP support is always enabled
property.description: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) support. Support is always enabled.

property.name: UseIPv6
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv6 address support is always enabled
property.description: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates IPv6 address support. Support is always enabled.

property.name: UseDHCP
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv4 autoconfiguration with DHCP is controlled by the IP address configuration mode
property.description: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates whether to support DCHP autoconfiguration for IPv4 IP addresses. IPv4 autoconfiguration with DHCP is control by the IP address configuration mode.

property.name: UseSLAAC
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv6 autoconfiguration with SLAAC is controlled by the IP address configuration mode
property.description: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates whether to support SLAAC autoconfiguration for IPv6 IP addresses. IPv6 autoconfiguration with SLAAC is control by the IP address configuration mode.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: IPConfigMode
property.summary: Set the configuration mode for the interface.

description.p: The configuration mode of the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.

ul.li:
With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface.
Assign the primary network address.
Manage secondary, or auxiliary, network addresses.
Assign the default IPv4 gateway.
Assign the default IPv6 gateway, if you define IPv6 IP addresses.
Manage static routes in the routing table.
With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.
With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

hoverhelp.p: Set the configuration mode for the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.

ul.li: With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface.
With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.
With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Set the primary IP address and netmask.

description.p: The IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.

ul.li: For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.
For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

hoverhelp.p: Set the IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.

ul.li: For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.
For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.summary: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway.
property.description: The IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.
property.hoverhelp: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.

property.name: DefaultIPv6Gateway
property.summary: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway.
property.description: The IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway. If you do not use IPv6 network addresses, do not define this property.
property.hoverhelp: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway.

property.name: SecondaryAddress
property.summary: Set secondary IP addresses and netmasks.

description.p: The IP addresses and netmasks of secondary IP addresses. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.

ul.li: For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.
For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

hoverhelp.p: Set the IP address and netmask of the secondary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.

ul.li: For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.
For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

property.name: StaticRoutes
property.summary: Manage the static routes in the routing table.
property.description: The static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network. When the appliance connects to a remote address, the static route with the longest prefix match is used. If multiple routes have the same prefix match, the static route with the lowest metric is used. If the metric is the same, the static route is chosen randomly.
property.hoverhelp: Manage the static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network.

property.name: DADTransmits
property.summary: Set the number of IPv6 duplication address detection attempts.
property.description: The number of IPv6 duplication address detection (DAD) attempts. The default value is 1.

property.name: DADRetransmitTimer
property.summary: Set the delay between IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) attempts.
property.description: The delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. The default value is 1000. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.
property.hoverhelp: Set the delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.

property.name: StandbyControl
property.summary: Indicate whether to allow a standby configuration.

description.p: Whether to allow a standby configuration. The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic.
Attention: Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

property.name: Group
property.summary: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.

description.p: The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition.
Attention: Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP).
The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration.

ul.li: Belong to the same group.
Use the same primary virtual IP address.
Use the same authentication, or security token.

property.name: VirtualIP
property.summary: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.

description.p: The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address.
Attention: Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

property.name: SecondaryVirtualIP
property.summary: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.

description.p: Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address.
Attention: Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

property.name: Preempt
property.summary: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.

description.p: Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure.

ul.li: When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member.
When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member.

description.p: Attention: Do not enable preemption.

hoverhelp.p: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group. Attention: Do not enable preemption.

property.name: Priority
property.summary: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.

description.p: The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.

For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.

property.hoverhelp: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.

property.name: SelfBalance
property.summary: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.

description.p: Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.

ul.li: When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.

When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.

description.p: The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint.

ul.li: In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause.

In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.

hoverhelp.p: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.

ul.li: When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.

When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.

property.name: Authentication
property.summary: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.
property.description: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.
property.hoverhelp: Set the authentication string, or security token in hex. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

property.name: HelloTimer
property.summary: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages
property.description: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.
property.hoverhelp: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40.

property.name: HoldTimer
property.summary: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.
property.description: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.
property.hoverhelp: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120.

property.name: DistAlg
property.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.
property.description: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

object.name: EthernetInterface

property.name: LinkAggMode
property.summary: Indicate whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface.
property.description: Whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface. When part of a link aggregation interface, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface. When part of a link aggregation interface, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

property.name: MTU
property.summary: Set the maximum transmission unit for the Ethernet interface.

description.p: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the Ethernet interface. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation. Set the value greater than 1500 bytes only when you know that all other interfaces on this network are similarly configured. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500.

ul.li: When the Ethernet interface is part of a VLAN interface, the MTU of the VLAN interface cannot be greater than the MTU for the Ethernet interface The appliance adds 4 bytes when a VLAN interface is enabled on this interface.
When the Ethernet interface is part of a link aggregation interface, the MTU of the aggregate interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface.

property.hoverhelp: Set the maximum transmission unit for the Ethernet interface. Set the value to greater than 1500 bytes only when you know that all other interfaces on this network are similarly configured. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128.

property.name: MACAddress
property.summary: Override the assigned 48-bit MAC address.
property.description: The MAC address of the Ethernet interface. By default, the appliance uses the burned-in MAC address from the network interface controller that was assigned when the system was manufactured. Enter a 48-bit hex MAC address in the 00:12:34:56:78:9c format. The value must be a unicast address, where the first byte must be even.
property.hoverhelp: Override the assigned 48-bit MAC address. By default, the appliance uses the burned-in MAC address from the network interface controller. Enter a 48-bit hex MAC address in the 00:12:34:56:78:9c format. The value must be a unicast address, where the first byte must be even.

property.name: Mode
property.summary: Set the Ethernet physical mode.
property.description: The phyical mode is the interface speed and direction of the Ethernet unshielded twisted pair physical (PHY) layer. Use this property to set speed and direction explicitly when your networking equipment does not negotiate properly. If you manually configure one end of the link, you must manually configure the other end of the link to the same setting.
property.hoverhelp: Set the Ethernet physical mode. Use this property to set speed and direction explicitly when your networking equipment does not negotiate properly.

property.name: ForceMode
property.summary: Indicate whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior.
property.description: Whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior. By default, this option is disabled, which means that autonegotiation is used. When this option is enabled, the physical mode is forced, and there is no autonegotiation performed at the Ethernet driver level. Enable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior. Enable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

property.name: HardwareOffload
property.summary: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.

description.p: Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled.

ul.li: When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of Ethernet device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance.
When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

description.p: If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

property.name: FlowControl
property.summary: Set the flow control mode.
property.description: The flow control mode of the Ethernet interface. The default value is Auto. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
property.hoverhelp: Set the flow control mode. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

object.description: Configure and manage Ethernet interfaces.

object.name: LinkAggregation

property.name: Type
property.summary: Set the mode for link aggregation.
property.description: The mode to use for link aggregation. When the link aggregation interface uses LACP, you can change the selection policy and the distribution algorithm for outbound packets.

property.name: Links
property.summary: Manage Ethernet interfaces in the link aggregation interface.

description.p:
The Ethernet interfaces in the link aggregation interface. Although you can add members in the following situations, the operational state of the link aggregation interface is down.
The Ethernet interface is part of a VLAN interface.
The Ethernet interface is part of another link aggregation interface.
The Ethernet interface is not enabled for link aggregation.

property.name: MTU
property.summary: Set the maximum transmission unit for the link aggregation interface.
property.description: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the link aggregation interface. The MTU of the link aggregation interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation.
property.hoverhelp: Set the maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the link aggregation interface. The MTU of the link aggregation interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128.

property.name: LACPAggregatorSelectionPolicy
property.summary: Set the algorithm for the LACP selection policy.
property.description: The algorithm for the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) selection policy. When there is more than one LACP aggregator for the members of an LACP aggregation, the appliance uses the algorithm to determine which aggregator to use. In other words, the algorithm determines which group of link aggregation interfaces is active.
property.hoverhelp: Set the algorithm for the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) selection policy. When there is more than one LACP aggregator for the members of an LACP aggregation, the appliance uses the algorithm to determine which aggregator to use. In other words, the algorithm determines which group of link aggregation interfaces is active.

property.name: TransmitHashingAlgorithm
property.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for outbound packets among the active physical interfaces in an LACP aggregation.
property.description: The distribution algorithm for outbound packets among the active physical interfaces in an Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) aggregation. The default algorithm uses uses both MAC addresses and IP addresses.

property.name: LACPRate
property.summary: Set the rate in the LACP aggregation.
property.description: The rate of the LACP aggregation, which can be slow (every 30 seconds) or fast (every 1 second).

property.name: HardwareOffload
property.summary: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.

description.p: Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled.

ul.li: When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of Ethernet device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance.
When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

description.p: If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

object.summary: Configure and manage link aggregation interfaces.
object.description: A link aggregation interface combines multiple Ethernet ports. When combined and used in parallel, the aggregate interface increases link speed beyond a single Ethernet port. Because the aggregate interface combines Ethernet ports, redundancy is increased to provider higher availability.

object.name: VLANInterface

property.name: OverType
property.summary: Set the parent interface type.
property.description: The parent interface type for the VLAN interface.

property.name: EthernetInterface
property.summary: Set the parent Ethernet interface.
property.description: The parent Ethernet interface for the VLAN interface.

property.name: LinkAggInterface
property.summary: Set the parent link aggregation interface.
property.description: The parent link aggregation interface for the VLAN interface.

property.name: Identifier
property.summary: Set the unique VLAN identifier.
property.description: The unique VLAN identifier to send and receive traffic. The identifier must be unique among all VLAN interfaces on the same Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 1 - 4094. The default value is 2.
property.hoverhelp: Set the VLAN identifier that is unique among all VLAN interfaces on the same Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 1 - 4094.

property.name: DefaultOutboundPriority
property.summary: Set the priority for outbound packets.

description.p: The priority value for outbound VLAN headers for packets. These packets are sent on this VLAN interface. This value is placed in the user_control field of the Tag Control Information (TCI). The exact interpretation of the value depends on the VLAN switch configuration. Enter a value in the range 0 - 7. The default value is 0.

hoverhelp.p: Set the priority value for outbound VLAN headers for packets. These packets are sent on this VLAN interface. This value is placed in the user_control field of the Tag Control Information (TCI). Enter a value in the range 0 - 7.

property.name: MTU
property.summary: Set the maximum transmission unit for the VLAN interface.
property.description: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the VLAN interface. The MTU for the VLAN interface cannot be greater than the MTU of the parent interface. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500.
property.hoverhelp: Set the maximum transmission unit for the VLAN interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128.

property.name: HardwareOffload
property.summary: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.

description.p: Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled.

ul.li: When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of VLAN device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance.
When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

description.p: If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

object.description: A VLAN interface allows multiple logical LANs to coexist on the same Ethernet segment. VLAN packets are identified by the IEEE 802.1Q protocol. You can define multiple VLAN interfaces on a single parent interface. The parent interface can be an Ethernet interface or a link aggregation interface.
Configure network Ethernet interfaces

object.name: IPMILanChannel

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation
property.description: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: MaximumPrivilegeLevel
property.summary: Maximum privilege level allowed on channel.
property.description: The maximum privilege level for all users on the LAN channel. Each IPMI command has a minimum privilege level. This property sets the maximum privilege level that a user can attain on the LAN channel even when that user has a greater privilege level.

property.name: SolEnabled
property.summary: LAN channel can support serial over LAN
property.description: Whether to support the serial over LAN protocol over Remote Control and Management Protocol Plus (RCMP+) on this channel.

property.name: SolRequiredUserPrivilegeLevel
property.summary: Privilege level for Serial-over-LAN
property.description: The required privilege level for users to use the serial over LAN protocol (payload) over RCMP+ on this LAN channel.

property.name: AllowedUser
property.summary: Users allowed to use this channel
property.description: The users allowed to use this LAN channel. For each user, include the maximum privilege level, whether to allow serial over LAN, and the maximum number of simultaneous sessions.

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: IP Address and mask
property.description: The IPv4 IP address and subnet mask to this interface. This IP address must be distinct from all IP addresses on the appliance and from all IP address on the connected subnet (broadcast domain).

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.summary: Default IP Gateway
property.description: The IPv4 default gateway that communicate with systems not on the local subnet. Without a default gateway, the LAN channel cannot communicate with clients that are not on the same local subnet (broadcast domain).

object.description: An Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) LAN channel allows access to the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) on the appliance over a LAN. IPMI allows remote management access and can provide serial over LAN to the console serial port. The LAN channel must use the 'mgt0' management Ethernet connector.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.
property.description: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: UserID
property.summary: IPMI identifier for the IPMI user
property.description: The IPMI identifier for the IPMI user. Each user must have a unique User ID. All configuration for the user in the BMC is indexed by this User ID. Use any value of 3 - 10. The default value is 3.

property.name: Password
property.summary: Password for remote authentication
property.description: The password that the remote user must present for authentication. The password must be between 8 and 16 characters in length. Because the password is in only the BMC, it will not be included as part of an export or backup operation. Because the password is not part of an export, it will not be added during an import or restore operation.

description.p: An Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) user can create, change, or destroy user authentication records in the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC). Authentication records allow users to communicate using IPMI protocols over external channels, such as an IPMI LAN channel. On an appliance, there can be eight IPMI users.

Note: If you apply the configuration but do not save it, the IPMI user data is written to the BMC but not saved to the startup configuration. In this situation, the IPMI user can connect to the serial port over the IPMI LAN channel.

object.name: IPMulticast

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: MulticastGroup
property.summary: Specifies the multicast IP group address.
property.description: Specifies the multicast IP group address. For IPv4, enter an address in the range 224.0.0.0 - 239.255.255.255. For IPv6, enter an address beginning with FF.

property.name: Interface
property.summary: Specifies the local IP address, host name, or host alias that is used to transmit and receive multicast messages.
property.description: The local IP interface address, host name, or host alias of the Ethernet interface or VLAN interface that is used to transmit and receive multicast messages. Specify an IP address, a host name, or an existing host alias that is mapped to an IP address.

property.name: Port
property.summary: Specifies the IP port used to transmit and receive multicast packets.
property.description: The IP port used to transmit and receive multicast packets. Enter a value in the range 1 - 0xFFFF.

property.name: SSKey
property.summary: The shared secret key to sign and verify packets.
property.description: The key is optional. If a key is not specified, the packets are not signed and verified. All peers in the peer group must be configured with an identical key.

property.name: MaxDataSize
property.summary: Specifies the maximum allowable size of a transmitted data block.
property.description: The maximum size of a transmitted data block within a multicast packet. The sum of the maximum transmit data size and the IP header should not exceed the MTU of the network.

property.name: NAKRetransmissionTime
property.summary: Specifies the length of time to wait before an NAK is initially transmitted or is retransmitted.
property.description: The length of time before the first NAK packet is transmitted or the length of time between subsequent NAK transmissions. Enter a value in the range 100 - 60000. The default value is 200.

property.name: NAKRetries
property.summary: Specifies the number of times a missing NAK packet is retransmitted.
property.description: The number of times that an NAK packet is retransmitted. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The default value is 5.

property.name: BufferResendTime
property.summary: Specifies the number of seconds that a transmitted packet remains buffered.
property.description: The number of seconds that a transmitted multicast packet remains buffered. Enter a value in the range 1 - 60. The default value is 2.

object.description: IP Multicast mode defines the properties for the multicast configuration used to transmit and receive peering update messages.

object.name: ISAMReverseProxy

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: ISAMRuntime
property.summary: The runtime controls access by components to a single configuration of IBM Security Access Manager.
property.description: The runtime controls access by components to a single configuration of IBM Security Access Manager.

property.name: LocalHost
property.summary: Enter the host name that is used by the IBM Security Access Manager policy server to contact the appliance.
property.description: The host name that is used by the IBM Security Access Manager policy server to contact the appliance. Valid values include any valid host name, IP address, or host alias. For example, libra.dallas.ibm.com

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Enter the listening port number for the administration service of the Access Manager Reverse Proxy.
property.description: The listening port number for the administration service of the Access Manager Reverse Proxy. The listening port is the port on which the Reverse Proxy and the Access Manager policy server communicate.

property.name: PrimaryInterface
property.summary: Enter the network interface on which the Reverse Proxy listens for requests.
property.description: The network interface on which the Reverse Proxy listens for requests.

property.name: Administrator
property.summary: Enter the name of the IBM Security Access Manager administrative user.
property.description: The name of the IBM Security Access Manager administrative user.

property.name: Password
property.summary: Enter the alias of the IBM Security Access Manager administrative user password.
property.description: The alias of the IBM Security Access Manager administrative user password. You can configure the password alias in the Password Map.

property.name: ISAMDomain
property.summary: Enter the name of the IBM Security Access Manager management domain.
property.description: The name of the IBM Security Access Manager management domain.

property.name: EnableHTTP
property.summary: Indicate whether HTTP access is allowed to the Access Manager Reverse Proxy instance.
property.description: Whether HTTP access is allowed to the Access Manager Reverse Proxy instance.

property.name: HTTPPort
property.summary: Enter the port number for insecure HTTP access.
property.description: The port number for insecure HTTP access.

property.name: EnableHTTPS
property.summary: Indicate whether HTTPS access is allowed to the Access Manager Reverse Proxy instance.
property.description: Whether HTTPS access is allowed to the Access Manager Reverse Proxy instance.

property.name: HTTPSPort
property.summary: Enter the port number for secure HTTP access.
property.description: The port number for secure HTTP access.

property.name: ClusterMaster
property.summary: Indicate whether this proxy server acts as the cluster master when the proxy clustering functionality is used.
property.description: If the proxy clustering functionality is used, controls whether this proxy server acts as the cluster master.

property.name: MasterInstance
property.summary: Enter the server name for the proxy instance that acts as the master in the cluster.
property.description: The server name for the proxy instance that acts as the master in the cluster.

property.name: ClientPersistentConnTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of seconds that a persistent connection with a client can remain inactive before it is closed by the server.
property.description: The maximum number of seconds that a persistent connection with a client can remain inactive before it is closed by the server. Enter a value in the range 0 - 2147483647. The default value is 5.

property.name: WorkerThreads
property.summary: Enter the number of threads to allocate to service requests.
property.description: The number of threads that are allocated to service requests. The minimum value is 1. The default value is 300.

property.name: UserRegistrySSL
property.summary: Indicate whether to enable SSL communication between the proxy server and the LDAP server.
property.description: Specifies whether to enable SSL communication between the proxy server and the LDAP server.

property.name: UserRegistrySSLPort
property.summary: Enter the port number on which SSL communication takes place between the proxy server and the LDAP server.

description.p: Specifies the port number on which SSL communication takes place between the proxy server and the LDAP server.
Note: The ssl-port parameter of the [ldap] stanza of the Access Manager Runtime's ldap.conf file takes precedence of the value that you enter here.

property.name: UserRegistryCertDB
property.summary: Set the LDAP key file.
property.description: Specifies the LDAP key file.

property.name: UserRegistryCertLabel
property.summary: Enter the LDAP client certificate label.
property.description: Specifies the LDAP client certificate label. When SSL communication is enabled between the proxy and the LDAP server, SSL does not require an LDAP client certificate label.

property.name: SSLCertKeyFile
property.summary: Specify the key database which is used to store the certificates that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy presents to the client
property.description: The key database which is used to store the certificates that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy presents to the client.

property.name: SSLServerCert
property.summary: The name of the SSL certificate, in the key database, which is presented to the client
property.description: The name of the SSL certificate, in the key database, which is presented to the client.

property.name: JunctionCertKeyFile
property.summary: Specify the key database to store the certificates that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy presents to the junctioned Web server
property.description: The key database which is used to store the certificates that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy presents to the junctioned Web server.

property.name: Junctions
property.summary: Specify one or more Access Manager junctions.
property.description: Access Manager junctions.

property.name: JunctionHTTPTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of seconds that the appliance waits to send to and read from a TCP junction.
property.description: The maximum number of time for sending to and reading from a TCP junction. The default value is 120.

property.name: JunctionHTTPSTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of seconds that the appliance waits to send to and read from an SSL junction.
property.description: The maximum number of time for sending to and reading from an SSL junction. The default value is 120.

property.name: JunctionMaxCachedPersistentConns
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of connections between the proxy and a junctioned Web server to cache for future use
property.description: The maximum number of connections that can be cached for future use between the proxy and a junctioned Web server.

property.name: JunctionPersistentConnTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum length of time that a cached connection with a junctioned Web server can remain idle before it is closed by the Access Manager Reverse Proxy.
property.description: The maximum length of time that a cached connection with a junctioned Web server can remain idle before it is closed by the Access Manager Reverse Proxy. The default value is 0, which means disabled.

property.name: ManagedCookieList
property.summary: A pattern matched and comma separated list of cookie names for those cookies that are stored in the Access Manager Reverse Proxy cookie jar.
property.description: A pattern matched and comma separated list of cookie names for those cookies that are stored in the Access Manager Reverse Proxy cookie jar. Other cookies that do not match these patterns are returned to the client.

property.name: HealthCheckPingInterval
property.summary: Enter the interval between requests that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy sends to junctioned Web servers to determine the state of the junctioned Web servers.
property.description: The interval between requests that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy sends to junctioned Web servers to determine the state of the junctioned Web servers.

property.name: HealthCheckPingMethod
property.summary: Enter the HTTP method that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy uses when it sends health check requests to the junctioned Web server.
property.description: The HTTP method that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy uses when it sends health check requests to the junctioned Web server.

property.name: HealthCheckPingURI
property.summary: Enter the URI that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy uses when sending health check requests to the junctioned Web server.
property.description: The URI that the Access Manager Reverse Proxy uses when it sends health check requests to the junctioned Web server.

property.name: BasicAuthTransport
property.summary: The transport protocol over which basic authentication is supported.
property.description: The transport protocol over which basic authentication is supported.

property.name: BasicAuthRealm
property.summary: Enter the realm name for basic authentication.
property.description: Realm name for basic authentication.

property.name: ClientCertAccept
property.summary: Indicate how the Access Manager Reverse Proxy handles client certificate from clients.
property.description: Defines how the Access Manager Reverse Proxy handles client certificate from clients.

property.name: ClientCertEAIURI
property.summary: Enter the resource identifier of the EAI application that is invoked to perform external client certificate authentication
property.description: The resource identifier of the External Authentication Interface (EAI) application that is invoked to perform external client certificate authentication.

property.name: ClientCertData
property.summary: Specify the client certificate data that is passed to the EAI application.
property.description: The client certificate data that is passed to the External Authentication Interface (EAI) application.

property.name: EAITransport
property.summary: The transport protocol for EAI.
property.description: The transport protocol for the External Authentication Interface (EAI).

property.name: EAITriggerURL
property.summary: A URL pattern that is used to determine whether a response should be examined for EAI authentication headers
property.description: A URL pattern that is used to determine whether a response should be examined for External Authentication Interface (EAI) authentication headers.

property.name: AuthLevels
property.summary: Set the authentication levels.
property.description: The authentication levels.

property.name: FormsAuthTransport
property.summary: The transport over which forms authentication is supported
property.description: The transport over which forms authentication is supported.

property.name: KerberosTransport
property.summary: Specifies the transport for which authentication using the SPNEGO authentication mechanism is enabled
property.description: Specifies the transport for which authentication using the SPNEGO authentication mechanism is enabled.

property.name: KerberosKeytab
property.summary: Specify the name of the Kerberos keytab file.
property.description: The name of the Kerberos keytab file. The keytab file must contain keys for each of the SPNs used for SPNEGO authentication.

property.name: KerberosUseQDN
property.summary: Indicate whether to include the domain portion of the principal name as part of the user ID.
property.description: Whether to include the domain portion of the principal name as part of the user ID. Kerberos authentication provides a principal name in the shortname@domain.com form. By default, only the short name portion is used as the user ID. When enabled, the domain portion is also included as part of the user ID.

property.name: KerberosServiceNames
property.summary: Specifies the list of the Kerberos Service Principal Names (SPNs) for the server.
property.description: Specifies the list of the Kerberos service principal names for the server.

property.name: SessionReauthenForInactive
property.summary: Prompt users to re-authenticate if their entry in the server credential cache times out because of inactivity.

description.p: Prompt users to re-authenticate if their entry in the server credential cache times out because of inactivity.

ul.li: When disabled, entries in the cache are deleted when the inactivity timeout is reached.
When enabled, entries in the cache are retained until the cache lifetime timeout is reached.
If the inactivity timeout is reached and the client makes another request before the cache lifetime timeout is reached, users are prompted to re-authenticate.

property.name: SessionMaxCacheEntries
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of concurrent entries in the session cache.
property.description: The maximum number of concurrent entries in the session cache. The default value is 4096.

property.name: SessionLifetimeTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum lifetime for an entry in the session cache.
property.description: Maximum lifetime for an entry in the session cache.

property.name: SessionInactiveTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum time that a session can remain idle before it is removed from the session cache.
property.description: The maximum time that a session can remain idle before it is removed from the session cache.

property.name: SessionTCPCookie
property.summary: The name of the cookie to be used to hold the HTTP session identifier
property.description: The name of the cookie to be used to hold the HTTP session identifier.

property.name: SessionSSLCookie
property.summary: The name of the cookie to be used to hold HTTPS session identifier
property.description: The name of the cookie to be used to hold HTTPS session identifier.

property.name: SessionUseSame
property.summary: Indicate whether to use the same session for both HTTP and HTTPS requests.
property.description: Whether to use the same session for both HTTP and HTTPS requests.

property.name: HTMLRedirect
property.summary: Indicate whether to enable the HTML redirect functionality.
property.description: Whether to enable the HTML redirect functionality.

property.name: LocalRespRedirect
property.summary: Indicate whether to enable the local response redirect functionality.
property.description: Whether to enable the local response redirect functionality.

property.name: LocalRespRedirectURI
property.summary: Enter the URI to which the client is redirected for generated responses.
property.description: The URI to which the client is redirected for generated responses.

property.name: LocalRespRedirectMacros
property.summary: Specify the macro information to include in the local response redirect.
property.description: The macro information that are included in the local response redirect.

property.name: FailoverTransport
property.summary: The transport over which failover authentication is supported
property.description: The transport over which failover authentication is supported.

property.name: FailoverCookiesLifetime
property.summary: Enter the maximum lifetime for failover cookies.
property.description: Maximum lifetime for failover cookies.

property.name: FailoverCookiesKeyFile
property.summary: The key file to encrypt the failover cookies
property.description: The key file that encrypts the failover cookies.

property.name: CDSSOTransport
property.summary: The transport over which CDSSO authentication is supported
property.description: The transport over which cross-domain single sign-on (CDSSO) authentication is supported.

property.name: CDSSOTransportGen
property.summary: The transport over which the creation of CDSSO tokens is supported
property.description: The transport over which the creation of cross-domain single sign-on (CDSSO) tokens is supported.

property.name: CDSSOPeers
property.summary: The name of the other proxy servers in the CDSSO domain, along with the name of the key file for the various proxy servers.
property.description: The name of the other proxy servers which are participating in the CDSSO domain, along with the name of the key file which will be used by the various proxy servers.

property.name: LTPATransport
property.summary: The transport over which LTPA authentication is supported
property.description: The transport over which LTPA authentication is supported.

property.name: LTPACookie
property.summary: The name of the cookie that transports the LTPA token
property.description: The name of the cookie that is used to transport the LTPA token.

property.name: LTPAKeyFile
property.summary: The key file used to access LTPA cookies
property.description: The key file used when accessing to access LTPA cookies.

property.name: LTPAKeyFilePw
property.summary: The password used to access the LTPA key file
property.description: The password used to access the LTPA key file.

property.name: LTPAKeyFilePwAlias
property.summary: The password alias of the password used to access the LTPA key file
property.description: The password alias of the password used to access the LTPA key file.

property.name: ECSSOTransport
property.summary: The transport over which e-community SSO authentication is supported
property.description: The transport over which e-community single signon (ECSSO) authentication is supported.

property.name: ECSSOName
property.summary: Enter the name of the e-community
property.description: Name of the e-community.

property.name: ECSSOIsMasterAuthServer
property.summary: Indicate whether this Access Manager Reverse Proxy instance is the master for the e-community.
property.description: Whether this Access Manager Reverse Proxy instance is the master for the e-community.

property.name: ECSSOMasterAuthServer
property.summary: Enter the name of the Access Manager Reverse Proxy server that acts as the master of the e-community.
property.description: The name of the Access Manager Reverse Proxy server that acts the master of the e-community.

property.name: ECSSODomains
property.summary: The name of the other Access Manager Reverse Proxy servers in the e-community, along with the name of the key file for the various proxy servers.
property.description: The name of the other Access Manager Reverse Proxy servers that participate in the e-community, along with the name of the key file for the various proxy servers.

property.name: AgentLogging
property.summary: Indicate whether to enable the agent log.
property.description: Whether to enable the agent log.

property.name: RefererLogging
property.summary: Indicate whether to enable the referer log.
property.description: Whether to enable the referer log.

object.summary: Configure and manage Access Manager junctions.
object.description: An Access Manager junction logically combines the Web space of the Web application server with the Web space of the Access Manager Reverse Proxy server, resulting in a unified view of the entire Web object space. A junction allows the Access Manager Reverse Proxy to provide protective services on behalf of the Web application server.

property.name: PolicyServerHost
property.summary: Specifies the host name or IP address of the IBM Security Access Manager policy server (pdmgrd)

description.p: Specifies the host name or IP address of the IBM Security Access Manager policy server (pdmgrd). The policy server manages the policy database (sometimes referred to as master authorization database), updates the database replicas whenever a change is made to the master database, and replicates the policy information throughout the domains. The policy server also maintains location information about other resource managers that operate in the domain.

You must define at least one policy server for each domain. You can specify the host name with or without the domain extension. You can specify the fully qualified host name with or without the domain extension. Examples: pdmgr or pdmgr.tivoli.com

object.description: Each DataPower appliance domain can include a single Access Manager Runtime configuration. Each Access Manager Runtime is configured independently against a remote IBM Security Access Manager policy server and can support one or more Access Manager Reverse Proxy instances.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: IScsiName
property.summary: iSCSI Name

description.p:
Specify a valid iSCSI Name for this HBA instance. The name can be between 1 and 244 characters in length. Sample formats of an ISCSI qualified name (IQN), based on IETF RFC 3720, are:
iqn.2001-04.com.example
iqn.2001-04.com.example:storage.disk2.sys1.xyz

property.name: UseDHCP
property.summary: Enable or disable DHCP
property.description: Set whether to use Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). When set to "on", enables DHCP. When set to "off", the default value, disables DHCP.

property.summary: IP address for HBA instance
property.description: Specify the IP address for this HBA instance.

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.summary: IP address of default gateway
property.description: Specify the IP address of the default gateway for this HBA instance.

description.p: The iSCSI protocol is deprecated.
The configuration of the iSCSI Host Bus Adapter (HBA). The iSCSI HBA is the hardware that is responsible for the management of iSCSI communications.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: IScsiName
property.summary: iSCSI Name

description.p:
Specify a valid iSCSI Name for the Initiator. If changed, this value overrides the default value that was assigned when the system was manufactured. The name can be between 1 and 244 characters in length. Sample formats of an ISCSI qualified name (IQN), based on IETF RFC 3720, are:
iqn.2001-04.com.example
iqn.2001-04.com.example:storage.disk2.sys1.xyz
The iSCSI protocol is deprecated.
The configuration of the iSCSI Initiator. The Initiator can only be modified if there are no active iSCSI targets.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: TargetName
property.summary: iSCSI Name for a remote target

description.p:
Specify a valid iSCSI Name for the iSCSI target. The name can be between 1 and 244 characters in length. Sample formats of an ISCSI qualified name (IQN), based on IETF RFC 3720, are:
iqn.2001-04.com.example
iqn.2001-04.com.example:storage.disk2.sys1.xyz

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Host name or IP address
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the remote iSCSI target.

property.name: PortNumber
property.summary: Port number
property.description: Specify the IP port number to connect to the remote iSCSI target. If not specified, the value defaults to 3260.

property.name: SessionReestablishTimeout
property.summary: Session reestablish timeout in seconds

description.p: The amount of time that the DataPower iSCSI initiator will attempt to reestablish a connection to this remote iSCSI target.

Specify the number of seconds to wait for an operation on this iSCSI target to complete before considering the operation to have failed. The default is 120 seconds. Setting this value too low may cause operations that would have completed successfully to fail due to intermittent network issues.

If the appliance fails to establish a connection to the iSCSI target within this timeout threshold, the default value of 120 seconds can lead to appliance-level hang-detection being triggered. If this occurs, set the iSCSI Target object's Session Reestablish Timeout to a lower value.

property.name: HBARef
property.summary: HBA instance to which to bind
property.description: Select the HBA instance to which to bind this target instance.

property.name: CHAPRef
property.summary: CHAP entry to which to assign
property.description: Select the CHAP entry to which to assign this target instance.

Defines the configuration of the connection instance to a remote iSCSI target.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Allow only file reads on this iSCSI Volume.
property.description: Set the access permission to files on the storage volume. When set to "on", the access permission is read-only. When set to "off", the default value, the access permission is read-write.

property.name: Directory
property.summary: Directory name
property.description: Specify the subdirectory in the local: and logstore: directories where the files on the storage volume are available. Each application domain contains these subdirectories. These subdirectories are not shared across application domains. The name can be up to 64 characters long. The name cannot start with a period. The name can consist of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numeric digits, dashes, underscores, and periods.

property.name: LunValue
property.summary: Logical Unit Number
property.description: Specify the Logical Unit Number (LUN). Use an integer in the range of 0 through 255.

property.name: TargetRef
property.summary: iSCSI target instance
property.description: Select the iSCSI target instance to which to bind this iSCSI volume.

description.p: The iSCSI protocol is deprecated.
File system operations for iSCSI devices.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: UserName
property.summary: Username to use for connecting to the server
property.description: Specifies the account name used to access the remote server.

property.name: Password
property.summary: Password to use for connecting to the server
property.description: Specifies the password used to access the remote server.

property.name: PasswordAlias
property.summary: Password alias of the password to use for connecting to the server
property.description: Specifies the password alias of the password used to access the remote server.

property.name: Transactional
property.summary: Acknowledges messages only if transaction was successful.

description.p: Enables (on) or disables (off) transaction-based processing in which messages are acknowledged only after the transaction has succeeded.
Transaction-based processing is disabled by default.

property.name: MemoryThreshold
property.summary: Maximum memory size allowed for pending messages

description.p: Specifies the maximum memory allocation for pending messages.
Enter an integer (within the range 1048576 through 1073741824) that specifies the maximum memory (in bytes) allocated for pending messages.
By default, the maximum memory allocation is set at 268,435,456 bytes.

property.name: MaximumMessageSize
property.summary: Maximum message size the appliance sends to the remote server

description.p: Specifies the maximum message size that the appliance supports over a connection to the remote server.
Enter an integer (with the range 0 through 1073741824) that specifies the maximum message size in bytes.
By default, the maximum message size is set at 1048576 bytes.
You can use the special value, 0, to disable the enforcement of maximum message sizes.

property.name: DefaultMessageType
property.summary: Default Message Type

description.p: Select the default message type. This property is used only when the message type cannot be determined from the message headers.
On the transaction level, the DP_JMSMessageType header can change this setting.

property.name: TotalConnectionLimit
property.summary: Total number of connections limit

description.p: Specifies the maximum number of simultaneous open connections to the remote server.

Session requests in excess of the total allowable number of sessions per connection trigger the establishment of a new connection to the remote server. The appliance cannot establish a new connection unless the number of concurrent connections is less than the allowable total number of connections.

For example, with values of 20 for sessions per connection, 5 for connection limit and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, then a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection.

property.name: SessionsPerConnection
property.display: Maximum number of Sessions per Connection
property.summary: Maximum number of sessions per connection

description.p: Specifies the maximum number of concurrent multiplexed sessions supported by a single connection to the remote server. Enter any value of 1 - 65535. The default is 100.

Session requests in excess of the value set by this property trigger the establishment of a new connection to the remote server. The appliance cannot establish a new connection unless the number of concurrent connections is less than the allowable total number of connections.

For example, with values of 20 for sessions per connection, 5 for connection limit and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, then a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection.

property.name: AutoRetry
property.summary: Advanced recovery after critical error.
property.description: Enables (on, the default state) or disables (off) an automatic critical error-recovery procedure that attempts to re-establish a connection that has been broken in response to an error condition.

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Seconds to wait before retrying failing connections.

description.p: If Automatic Retry is enabled (the default state), specifies the interval in seconds between connection re-establishment attempts.

property.name: SSLProfile
property.summary: The cryoto profile is deprecated. Use an SSL client profile.

description.p: Identifies the client crypto profile to establish a secured (SSL-enabled) connection to the server. Without a crypto profile, the appliance establishes a nonsecure connection (no SSL support) to the server.
When defined for a WebSphere JMS Server, the cipher suite associated with the profile is replaced by an IBM default cipher suite (SSL_RSS_WITH_NULL_MD5).

property.name: EnableLogging
property.summary: Enable JMS-specific logging
property.description: Enables (on) or disables (off, the default state) an expanded JMS logging facility.

property.name: SSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between the appliance and its targets
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between the appliance and its targets.

property.name: SSLClient
property.summary: Set the SSL client profile to secure connections between the appliance and its targets
property.description: The SSL client profile to secure connections between the appliance and its targets.

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: XML Manager
property.description: Invisible dependency on default XML Manager.

object.name: TibcoEMSServer

property.name: LBAndFTPairs
property.summary: Load Balancing/Fault-Tolerance

description.p: Defines a series of servers for load-balancing, each with an optional backup servers for fault-tolerance. For load-balancing, select the algorithm from the Load Balancing Algorithm list on the Main tab.
Note: The definition of any server for load-balancing or fault-tolerance overrides the value of the TIBCO EMS Server Host property on the Main tab.

property.name: HostName
property.summary: Host name or IP address

description.p: Specify the host name or IP address with the listening port of the server in the host : port format. Without the port specification, the default is port 7222.
Note: This property is a required property. However if this configuration defines load-balancing or fault-tolerance behavior on the Load Balancing/Fault-Tolerance tab, this property is ignored.

property.name: ConnectionClientID
property.summary: Connection Client identifier
property.description: Specify the string to set as the TIBCO EMS Connection Client identifier.

property.name: LoadBalancingAlgorithm
property.summary: Algorithm to balance the real servers.
property.description: Select the algorithm to use to balance the real servers.

object.description: TIBCO EMS Server is responsible for messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager.

object.name: WebSphereJMSServer

property.name: Endpoint
property.summary: WebSphere JMS Endpoint

description.p: Identifies the connection host, port, and protocol to use for the bootstrap process.

A service integration bus (SIB) supports applications using message-based and service-oriented architectures. A bus is a group of interconnected servers and clusters that have been added as members of the bus. Applications connect to a bus at one of the messaging engines associated with its bus members.
A messaging engine is a component, running inside a server, that manages messaging resources for a bus member. Applications are connected to a messaging engine when accessing a SIB.

Applications (such as the JMS object) running outside the WebSphere environment cannot locate directly a suitable messaging engine to connect to the target bus. In such cases the remote clients or servers must access the bus through a bootstrap server that is a member of the target bus. A bootstrap server is an application server running the SIB process, but need not be running any message engines. Rather the bootstrap server selects a messaging engine that is running in an application server that supports the bootstrap protocol requested by the remote device.

To connect to a messaging engine the remote application first connects to a bootstrap server. The bootstrap server selects a messaging engine and tells the client application to connect to that message engine to gain bus access.
A bootstrap server uses a host name or IP address, a port number, and a bootstrap transport chain (which identifies the protocol stack offered by the bootstrap server) to define an endpoint address.
The transport chain used for bootstrap access does not need to match the transport chain that is used for message exchange.
You can add multiple nondefault bootstrap servers. For failover capability, the endpoints must be members of the same WebSphere Application Server cluster.

property.name: TargetTransportChain
property.summary: WebSphere JMS Target Transport Chain

description.p: Identifies the predefined transport chain provided by the WebSphere Application Server, and used for message exchange between the application server and the WAS JMS object.
This property takes one of the following values.
(The default) Specifies the predefined InboundBasicMessaging transport chain (JFAP-TCP/IP).
Specifies the predefined InboundHTTPMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTP wrappers).
Specifies the predefined InboundHTTPSMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTPS wrappers).
Specifies the predefined InboundSecureMessaging transport chain (JFAP-SSL-TCP/IP).
If you have access to the WebSphere Administrative Console, you can view transport chain information through the Application Servers/serverName/Transport Chain menu.
The transport chain used for message exchange need not match the chain used for bootstrap access.

property.name: MessagingBus
property.summary: WebSphere JMS Messaging Bus

description.p: Identifies the Service Integration Bus (SIB) used to access the remote WebSphere Application Server.
A bus supports applications using message-based and service-oriented architectures. A bus is a group of interconnected servers and clusters that have been added as members of the bus.
Applications connect to a bus at one of the messaging engines associated with its bus members.

If you have access to the WebSphere Administrative Console, you can view bus information, to include bus members and messaging engines, queues and topics, and the bus-specific default topic space through the Service integration/Buses menu.

property.name: SSLCipher
property.summary: WebSphere JMS SSL Cipher Specification
property.description: Select the IBM cipher specification that the assigned client crypto profile uses when establishing a secure connection to the WebSphere Application Server. The selected specification replaces the cipher suite that is assigned in the SSL profile configuration. The selected cipher must be compatible with the protocol of the client crypto profile.

property.name: FIPS
property.summary: FIPS compliant ciphers suite

description.p: Forces (on) or makes optional (off, the default value) the use of IBM FIPS-compliant cipher specifications.
Setting this property to on prevents the usage of non-FIPS compliant cipher specifications, and requires the use of one of the following cipher specifications.

ul.li: TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256
