object.description: WebSphere JMS is responsible for messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager.

object.name: JSONSettings

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation
property.description: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: JSONMaxNestingDepth
property.summary: Maximum number of levels to nest label-value pairs.
property.description: The maximum nesting depth provides threat protection by limiting the number of nested label-value pairs allowed in the JSON message. Enter a value in the range 64 - 256. The default value is 64.

property.name: JSONMaxLabelLength
property.summary: Maximum length of the label portion of label-value pairs.
property.description: The maximum label length limits the number of bytes in the label portion of the JSON label-value pair. The length includes any white space that is contained between quotation marks. Enter a value in the range 256 - 8192. The default value is 256.

property.name: JSONMaxValueLength
property.summary: Maximum number of bytes for string values of label-value pairs.
property.description: The maximum value length limits the number of bytes in the value portion of a label-value pair when the value is a string. The length includes any white space that is contained between quotation marks. Enter a value in the range 8192 - 5368709121. The default value is 8192.

property.name: JSONMaxNumberLength
property.summary: Maximum number of bytes for number values of label-value pairs.
property.description: The maximum number length limits the number of bytes in the value portion of a label-value pair when the value is a number. The number must be a contiguous string of bytes that contain no white space. The number can include a minus sign and a positive or negative exponent. Enter a value in the range 128 - 256. The default value is 128.

property.name: JSONDocumentSize
property.summary: Maximum size of the JSON message in bytes.
property.description: The maximum document size provides threat protection by limiting the number of bytes in the body of the JSON message. If the message is converted to JSONx, the maximum document size specifies the size before conversion to JSONx. Note that the document size of the JSON message and the size of the JSONx equivalent might differ. Enter a value in the range 4194304 - 5368709121. The default value is 4194304.

object.description: The JSON settings specify constraints for parsing JSON messages. JSON settings work in conjunction with the parser limits specified in the XML Manager. The more restrictive limits apply.

object.name: Language

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

object.description: The available languages. Before the appliance can support a language, its administrative state must be enabled. When a language is enable, you can set it as the system locale in the System Settings configuration. When multiple languages are enabled, browsers that connect to the appliance can view the interface in an enabled language.

object.name: LDAPConnectionPool

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation
property.description: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Timeout in seconds for idle LDAP connections
property.description: Indicates the length of time that an LDAP connection can remain idle in the LDAP connection pool before the connection is removed from the connection pool. Enter a value in the range 1-86400. The default value is 120.

property.name: MaxPoolSize
property.summary: The maximum number of LDAP connections for a server:port:BindDN combination
property.description: Indicates the maximum number of LDAP connections that can exist for a server:port:BindDN combination in an LDAP connection pool. Enter a value in the range 1-2000. The default value is 35.

property.name: RejectOnPoolLimit
property.summary: Whether to reject an incoming LDAP connection when pool limit is reached
property.description: Determines whether to reject an incoming LDAP request when the LDAP connection pool reaches the maximum pool size for a server:port:BindDN combination.

object.description: The LDAP Connection Pool settings specify the LDAP connection pool to use.

object.name: LoadBalancerGroup

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Contains a brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Algorithm
property.summary: Algorithm to balance the real servers.
property.description: Select the algorithm to use to balance the real servers.

property.name: RetrieveInfo
property.summary: Retrieve Workload Management Information
property.description: Use this setting to control whether this Load Balancer Group has membership and weight information automatically retrieved from the work load management repository WebSphere Cell. If off is selected, the static configuration for this Load Balancer Group will be used.

property.name: WLMRetrieval
property.summary: Workload Management Retrieval
property.description: Contains the back end work load management repository selection type. Select 'WebSphere Cell' if your back-end is a WebSphere Application Server (WAS) Network Deployment (ND) or WAS Virtual Enterprise (VE).

property.name: WebSphereCellConfig
property.summary: WebSphere Cell
property.description: If you selected 'WebSphere Cell' for Workload Management Retrieval, you need to select a WebSphere Cell object which retrieves this information. If no objects are available in the pull down, you must create one.

property.name: WLMGroup
property.summary: Workload Management Group Name
property.description: The Workload Management Group Name is used to define a group. In a WebSphere Application Server environment, the back end group is a cluster name. Once specified, the Load Balancer Group will be populated with the members and weights retrieved from the back end.

property.name: WLMTransport
property.summary: Protocol used for this Load Balancer Group
property.description: Specify either HTTP or HTTPS for the Load Balancer Group protocol. This protocol is used to forward traffic between the DataPower appliance and the back end members of the Load Balancer Group.

property.name: Damp
property.summary: Timeout for down server
property.description: When a real server is observed to be non-functioning, it is temporarily disabled. When the damp time has elapsed, it is re-enabled. Allowable values are within the range of 1 through 86400 (seconds).

property.name: NeverReturnSickMember
property.summary: Block Connection Attempt When All Members Are Down
property.description: During normal operation, when all members of the load-balancing group are down and a new request for that group is made, the first member of the group is automatically selected. If this property is turned on, no attempt will be made to connect under these circumstances.

property.name: LBGroupMembers
property.summary: Group Membership

property.name: TryEveryServerBeforeFailing
property.summary: Try Every Server In Group Before Failing
property.description: This property applies only when none of the group members are in the "up" state. If this value is set, every server in the group is tried before failing the connection attempt. It is a "last best-effort" attempt.

property.name: LBGroupChecks
property.summary: Periodically Executed Health Check
property.description: The members of a Load Balancer Group can be periodically polled to verify the health of the server. If the server is found to be unresponsive, it is removed from the list of actively available servers until the unresponsive server passes a health check.

property.name: MasqueradeMember
property.description: If you set this value, the host name presented to the server will be the name of the group instead of the name of the member being used for that specific transaction.

property.name: ApplicationRouting
property.summary: Enables application routing with a WebSphere Cluster
property.description:
If set to on, the load balancer group will route to the back end cluster depending on the following conditions:
the application for which this request is targeted
the application status on the back end servers Application Routing is required for Application Edition (group or atomic) rollout. If you need Application Edition support, set the Update Type to Subscribe in the WebSphere Cell object.

property.name: LBGroupAffinityConf
property.summary: Session Affinity
property.description: Session affinity allows applications to maintain sessions with clients.

property.name: MonitoredCookies
property.summary: Monitored Cookies
property.description: The DataPower appliance enforces session affinity when the application server attempts to establish session affinity using one of these cookie names.

object.summary: Configure the members of a virtual group

description.p: The DataPower device distributes traffic to members of a Load Balancer Group. These are back end servers and not additional DataPower devices. A Load Balancer Group lists members of a virtual server group and sets the algorithm for balancing them. Periodic health checks can be performed. Load Balancers may also be used to provide redundant LDAP server access.
Once created, a top-level service (such as Multi-Protocol Gateway or XML Firewall) can use a Load Balancer Group by associating it with an XML manager that is associated with the top-level service.
The back end destination URL is set to the name of the Load Balancer Group (example: "BackEndServers").

object.name: LogLabel

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Log Category Type
property.description: Type of Log Category

object.description: Allows for the configuration of custom log categories

object.name: Luna

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.summary: Enter the IP address or hostname of the remote Luna HSM.
property.description: Specifies the IP address or host name of the Luna HSM where you store your RAS keys.

property.name: ServerCert
property.summary: Specify the certificate of the Luna HSM.
property.description: Specifies the public key that DataPower Gateway uses for encrypting the data that is sent to the Luna HSM.

property.name: SecurityOption
property.description: Select the security option for Luna HSM connection.

property.name: OTT
property.description: Specify the location of the one time token file. The token is required when you use host trust link (HTL) to provide an extra verification layer to secure the connection between the DataPower Gateway and the Luna HSM.

object.description: You can use a network-attached SafeNet Luna SA appliance as an HSM to provide secure storage for RSA keys and accelerate RSA operations remotely. The Luna HSM configuration sets up the connection between the DataPower Gateway and the Luna SA appliance.

object.name: LunaPartition

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: PartitionName
property.summary: Enter the partition name.
property.description: Specifies the name of the partition that is assigned to the DataPower Gateway for key storage. The name identifies the partition on the Luna HSM. The minimum length of the name is 1 character. The maximum length is 32 characters.

property.name: PartitionSerial
property.summary: Enter the serial number.
property.description: Specifies the serial number of the Luna HSM partition.

property.name: PasswordAlias
property.summary: Select the alias of the password required to access the partition.
property.description: Specifies the alias of the cleartext password that is required to access the partition.

object.description: The SafeNet Luna SA appliance stores the RSA keys in indepentent partitions. The Luna HSM partition configuration specifies the partition that the DataPower Gateway accesses in the Luna HSM.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: MatchRules
property.summary: Manage the rules in the matching rule.
property.description: The rules in the matching rule.

property.name: MatchWithPCRE
property.summary: Control whether the evaluation uses shell style expressions or PCREs.
property.description: Whether the evaluation uses shell style expressions or PCREs. This setting does not apply to XPath or HTTP method evaluations.

property.name: CombineWithOr
property.summary: Control whether to use Boolean OR or AND semantics during evaluation.

description.p: Whether to use Boolean OR or AND operations during evaluation.

ul.li: When enabled, combine with OR semantics. Only one match must evaluate to true for success.
When disabled, combine with AND semantics. All matches must evaluate to true for success.

object.name: MCFBase

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation

object.name: MCFCustomRule

property.name: CustomRuleName
property.summary: The name of the processing rule to invoke to retrieve the value.

property.name: CustomRuleValue
property.summary: The value to match

description.p: Enter the value to match against the value that is retrieved from the named processing rule. Enter either a string that must match the outcome of the rule or enter an asterisk (*) to match any value.
When the value is a string, an identical literal string comparison result is a match. When the value is an asterisk, any value other than NULL or an empty string results in a match.

object.summary: Filter based on a user created custom rule
object.description: A custom message content filter calls a processing rule to retrieve a specified value. The filter value is matched to the contents of variable 'var://context/policy/mcf/RULE-NAME'

object.name: MCFHttpHeader

property.name: HttpName
property.summary: Designate the name of the http header to retrieve the value for comparison.

property.name: HttpValue
property.summary: The value used for comparison for a HTTP header value match.

object.description: Filter based on HTTP header. A specific header value is used to match the request message.

object.name: MCFHttpMethod

property.name: HttpMethod
property.summary: Designate an HTTP method to specify as a service provider matching criteria.

object.summary: Filter based on the HTTP method
object.description: Filter based on the HTTP method. The filter value is matched to the HTTP method in the request message.

object.name: MCFHttpURL

property.name: HttpURLExpression
property.summary: Designate an expression to use to detect a URL match.

object.summary: Filter based on the request URL
object.description: Filter based on the request URL. The filter value is matched to the request URL.

object.name: MCFXPath

property.name: XPathExpression
property.summary: Designate the XPath used to retrieve the value for comparison.

property.name: XPathValue
property.summary: The value used for comparison for a XPath value match.

object.summary: Filter based on specific data in the message
object.description: Filter based on specific data in the message. An XPath expression defines a data element to be matched in the request message.

object.display: Message Content Filter Base Object Type

object.name: MessageContentFilters

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation

property.name: FilterRefs
property.summary: Message content filters objects reference by the group
property.description: Defines the group of message content filter objects.

property.name: Filters
property.summary: Message content filters in the group
property.description: Defines the group of message content filters.

object.summary: Manage a group of message content filters
object.description:
A Message Content Filters is a group of HTTP header-based and XPath-based filters.
For HTTP header-based filters, the filter succeeds when the name and value of an HTTP header field match.
For XPath-based filters, the filter succeeds when a document matches the element structure and content of the XPath expression and value.

object.name: FilterAction

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Action (Control procedure)
property.description: Select the action to take The default is Notify.

property.name: LogLevel
property.summary: Log message priority
property.description: Specify the priority of the log message that is generated when a monitored message type exceeds a threshold value.

property.name: BlockInterval
property.summary: The amount of time a monitor stays triggered
property.description: Specify an optional blackout period during which an over-threshold message type is denied service. Meaningful only when the message is rejected due to policy or shaping queue overflow. This value is the duration of service denial in milliseconds. The default value (0) indicates that while over-threshold messages are dropped, no service denial penalty is imposed.

object.description: On-Line Help for Monitor Policies (Filter Actions)

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Included address range
property.description: Use an IP network address and prefix length to define a contiguous range of IP addresses included in this traffic definition (for example, 10.10.100.0/28 specifies IP addresses 10.10.100.0 through 10.10.100.15, and 10.10.100.19/32 specifies a single host address).

property.name: IPExclude
property.summary: Excluded address range
property.description: Use an IP network address and prefix length to define a contiguous range of IP addresses excluded from this traffic definition (for example, 10.10.100.0/28 specifies IP addresses 10.10.100.0 through 10.10.100.15, and 10.10.100.19/32 specifies a single host address).

property.name: HTTPMethod
property.summary: HTTP method
property.description: Select the HTTP method included in this traffic definition. The default value is any, which indicates that HTTP method is not a match criteria.

property.name: HTTPHeader
property.summary: Included HTTP header field/values
property.description: Click this tab to add match criteria for inclusive HTTP header fields to the traffic definition. The field with its corresponding value must appear in the HTTP header of the message to qualify for inclusion.

property.name: HTTPHeaderExclude
property.summary: Excluded HTTP header field/values
property.description: Click this tab to add match criteria for exclusive HTTP header field to the traffic definition. The field with its corresponding value cannot appear in the HTTP header of the message to qualify for exclusion.

property.name: RequestURL
property.summary: Included URL set
property.description:
Provide a literal or wildcard expression to define a URL set included in this traffic definition. The following wildcard characters are available when defining the URL set.
asterisk (*)Matches 0 or more occurrences of any character
question mark (?)Matches one occurrence of any single character
brackets ( [ ] )Defines a character or numeric range. For example, [1-5] matches 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5, while xs[dl] matches xsd or xsl.

description.p: Message Matching determines what messages will be monitored by any monitor that uses the Message Matching object. It is a definition of the traffic flow that is monitored.
To capture all messages, set the HTTP Method field to 'any' and leave all other fields blank.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.
property.description: A Message Monitor observes traffic that is incuded by the Message Type definition (which in turn is a collection of Message Matching objects). The Monitor measures only that traffic selected by the Measure field. On the Filters page, traffic which meets the filter criteria causes the Monitor to take the corresponding action (which is defined by a Message Filter Type object).

property.name: MessageType
property.summary: Message type
property.description: Select the message type monitored by this message-count monitor.

object.name: CountMonitor

property.name: Measure
property.summary: Increment methods
property.description: Select the action that advances the counter. The default is Requests.

property.name: Source
property.summary: Aggregate/disaggregate IP addresses
property.description: Select how monitoring is applied to IP addresses. This setting is meaningful only if an associated traffic definition contains and inclusive or exclusive IP address criterion. The default is All.

property.name: Header
property.summary: The name of the header to extract IP address
property.description: The name of the HTTP header to read to determine the value of the source IP address.

property.name: Filter
property.description: Click this tab to define a message-count monitor threshold and assign an action (Message Filter Action) that is taken when the threshold is reached.

property.name: MaxSources
property.description: When utilizing the each-ip aggregate addressing policy the system organizes the counts per address by the addresses most recently used. When too many distinct counts have been observed, the Addresses not seen in the longest time are discarded. This parameter specifies how many distinct addresses are tracked.

object.description: On-Line Help for Message-Count Monitors

object.name: DurationMonitor

property.name: Measure
property.summary: Transaction cycle
property.description: Select which portion of the transaction cycle to monitor. The default is Messages.

property.name: Filter
property.description: Click this tab to define a message-duration monitor threshold and assign an action taken when the threshold is reached.

object.description: On-Line Help for Message-Duration Monitors. Duration Monitors observe the duration, or amount of time, taken to process submissions.

object.name: MessageType

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Matching
property.summary: A list of traffic definitions assigned to this message type
property.description: Use the values list (a list of traffic definitions), in conjunction with the Add and Delete buttons, to add one or more traffic definitions to this message type. Click the + button to create a new traffic definition (Message Matching object). Select an object and click ... to edit it.

object.description: On-Line Help for Message Types

object.name: MPGWErrorAction

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Error handling mode
property.description: Select which mode to handle the errors and generate the responses. The default mode is "Static (Local)".

property.name: RemoteURL
property.summary: Remote error page URL
property.description: Specify the URL of the remote error page.

property.name: LocalURL
property.summary: Local error page URL
property.description: Specify the URL of the local error page.

property.name: ErrorRule
property.summary: Processing rule for errors
property.description: Specify the custom error rule that the appliance runs to handle errors.

property.name: StatusCode
property.summary: HTTP status code
property.description: Specify the HTTP status code that the appliance returns to the client. Enter a value in the range 0 - 999.

property.name: ReasonPhrase
property.summary: HTTP reason phrase
property.description: Specify the HTTP reason phrase that the appliance returns to the client. For a proxy mode, the specified reason phrase overrides the fetched value.

property.name: HeaderInjection
property.summary: HTTP header to be injected
property.description: Specify the name and the value for the HTTP header that the appliance injects.

object.description: Define how the Multi-Protocol gateway handles errors and generates error responses to the client.

object.name: MPGWErrorHandlingPolicy

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation

property.name: PolicyMaps
property.summary: A list of matching rules and error actions
property.description: The policy maps contain a list of error response action rules and their corresponding matching rules. When the policy evaluates the matching rules and finds a match, it runs the corresponding error response action. The policy runs the first error response action with a successful match.

object.summary: Configured action to generate error responses for web requests
object.description: A Multi-Protocol gateway error policy consists of one or more error actions. A service runs an error action depending on whether or not a corresponding matching rule selects the action for processing. A service can have one policy active at a time. When an error occurs in the Multi-Protocol Gateway from an HTTP or HTTPS request flow and no precedent error handler handles the error, the service calls the error policy.

object.name: MQQM

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: HostName
property.summary: Host name or IP address with port

description.p: Specify the host name or IP address with the listening port of the IBM MQ server where the queue manager is running. If you do not specify the port, the default is 1414.
The value depends on IP family.

ul.li:
For IPv4
hostname:port -- For example, server1:1414
hostname(port) -- For example, server1(1414)
hostname -- For example, server1
address:port -- For example, 10.10.1.2:1414
address(port) -- For example, 10.10.1.2(1414)
address -- For example, 10.10.1.2

For IPv6
hostname:port -- For example, server1:1414
hostname(port) -- For example, server1(1414)
hostname -- For example, server1
[address]:port -- For example, [2202::148:248]:1414
address(port) -- For example, 2202::148:248(1414)
address -- For example, 2202::148:248

property.name: QMname
property.summary: Name of queue manager
property.description: Specify the name of the queue manager when the queue manager is not the default on the identified host.

property.name: CCSID
property.summary: Coded character set identifier (CCSID)
property.description: Specify the CCSID to present to the Queue Manager when the DataPower appliance connects to it. This setting has the same effect as setting the MQCCSID environment variable for an IBM MQ client. Refer to the IBM MQ Knowledge Center for more information and a list of specific CCSID values. Unless necessary, use the default value.

property.name: ChannelName
property.summary: Name of channel connection
property.description: Specify the name of the channel to use as an alternative to the default SYSTEM.DEF.SVRCONN.

property.name: CSPUserId
property.summary: User ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter

description.p: Specify the user ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.

p.p: The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the IBM MQ Queue Manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between the DataPower appliance and the IBM MQ server.

ul.li: If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, the DataPower appliance connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings.
If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.
If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.

property.name: CSPPassword
property.summary: Password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter

description.p: Specify the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.

p.p: The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the IBM MQ Queue Manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between DataPower and the IBM MQ server.

ul.li: If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, DataPower connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings.
If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.
If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.

property.name: CSPPasswordAlias
property.summary: Password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter

description.p: Specify the password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.

p.p: The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the IBM MQ Queue Manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between DataPower and the IBM MQ server.

ul.li: If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, DataPower connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings.
If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.
If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up.

property.name: Heartbeat
property.summary: Time between heartbeat flows
property.description: Specify the approximate time in seconds between heartbeat flows on a channel when waiting for a message on a queue. Use an integer between 0 and 999999. If 0, there will not be heartbeat flows exchanged when waiting for a message on the channel. This property does not set the heartbeat on the channel. Instead, it is used to negotiate the heartbeat value with the channel. The greater of the two values is used.

property.name: UserName
property.summary: Name that identifies this client
property.description: Specify the plaintext string to send to the server for identifying the client.

property.name: MaximumMessageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of messages to accept
property.description: Specify the maximum size in bytes of allowed messages. Use a value that is equal to or greater than the MaxMsgLength attribute of the channel and of the queue on the IBM MQ server. Messages that are bigger than this size are rejected. Use an integer between 1024 and 104857600.

property.name: CacheTimeout
property.summary: Maximum period to retain a dynamic connection in the connection cache

description.p: Specify the number of seconds that the DataPower appliance retains (keeps alive) a dynamic connection in the connection cache. Use a value that is greater than the negotiated heartbeat interval but less than the keep alive interval.

ul.li: The negotiated heartbeat interval is between the DataPower appliance and the backend IBM MQ server. Use the Channel Heartbeat property to define the starting value for the negotiation.

The keep alive (timeout) interval is on the backend IBM MQ server. The KAINT attribute on the IBM MQ server defines the timeout value for a channel. Not all channels have a defined, explicit keep alive interval on the IBM MQ server. Some queue managers use an automatic timeout setting (the KAINT attribute set to AUTO). In these cases, the keep alive interval is the negotiated heartbeat interval plus 60 seconds.

description.p: When an inactive connection reaches this threshold, the DataPower appliance removes that dynamic connection from the cache. When the cache no longer contains dynamic connections, the DataPower appliance deletes the dynamic queue manager. Without a dynamic queue manager, there is no connection with the backend IBM MQ server.

Note: The timeout value for the Cache Timeout property is the only way to configure a timeout value from the DataPower appliance to the backend IBM MQ server. No other configuration setting on the DataPower appliance can time out an IBM MQ connection.

property.name: UnitsOfWork
property.summary: Whether to use units-of-work

description.p: When set to 0 (zero), the default, causes the appliance to get and put messages with no provision for roll back. Either the operation succeeds or not. Undeliverable messages are silently discarded, which leaves higher level protocols with the responsibility to detect and retransmit lost packets

When set to 1, the DataPower appliance uses synch points. A synch point commits and rolls back each IBM MQ message, not the entire transaction. When specified, the DataPower appliance does not remove the message that it gets from a queue unitl it completes its transaction using that message (such as placing the message on a server queue for processing). If the transaction fails and the message is left available on the queue, the DataPower appliance can attempt to get the message and process it again.

p.b: Only the values 0 (zero) or 1 are valid.

property.name: AutomaticBackout
property.summary: Enables automatic routing of undeliverable messages

description.p: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the automatic backout of poison messages. A poison message is any message that the receiving application does not know how to process.
Usually an application rolls back the GET of this message, which leaves the message on the input queue. However, the backout count (MQMD.Backoutcount) is incremented.

As the IBM MQ Queue Manager continues to re-get the message, the backout count continues to increase. When the backout count exceeds the backout threshold, the IBM MQ Queue Manager moves the message to the backout queue.

If disabled, the poison message remains on the GET queue and continue to be reprocessed by the appliance until the Queue Manager that manages the GET queue removes it or the appliance reroutes the offending message. The message could be rerouted by a custom style sheet in the request rule.

property.name: BackoutThreshold
property.summary: Maximum number of reprocessing attempts
property.description: Specify the maximum number of reprocessing attempts to allow per message. During processing, the count starts at 0, which accounts for the initial reception of a message. If the initial attempt fails, the backout count is set to 1. After one failed attempt to reprocess the message, the count is set to 2. Therefore, the default value of 1 specifies two attempts: the initial attempt and a single reprocessing attempt.

property.name: BackoutQueueName
property.summary: Queue for undeliverable messages
property.description: Specify the queue to contains messages that exceeded the backout threshold. This queue must be managed by the same IBM MQ Queue Manager as the defined GET queue. The backout queue, typically SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE contains messages that cannot be processed or delivered.

property.name: TotalConnectionLimit
property.summary: Total number of TCP connections
property.description: Specify the total number of open TCP connections to allow. Use an integer between 1 and 10000. The default value is 250.

property.name: InitialConnections
property.summary: Number of preallocated TCP connections
property.description: Specify the number of TCP connections to open immediately when the IBM MQ Queue Manager starts. Use an integer between 0 and 10000. The default value is 1.

property.name: SharingConversations
property.summary: Maximum number of conversations to share in a TCP connection
property.description:
Specify the maximum number of conversations to share a single TCP/IP connection. Use an integer of 0 - 5000. To enable conversation sharing, specify a value that is greater than 1. A value of 0 (the default value) or 1 disables conversation sharing.
Note: You can only use sharing conversations when your IBM MQ Queue Manager connects to an IBM MQ server Version 7 or later.

property.name: ShareSingleConversation
property.summary: Use a single shared conversation

description.p: Specifies whether to enable conversation sharing between the DataPower appliance and the IBM MQ server when the number of shared conversations is 1.

property.name: SSLkey
property.summary: Filename of the key database

description.p: Specify the location of the key database file in which keys and certificates are stored.
Use this property with the SSL Cipher property to enable SSL communication when the SSL artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit).
Note: To integrate with IBM MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the SSL Client Profile property.

Each key database file has an associated stash file. The stash file holds encrypted passwords that allow programmatic access to the key database. The stash file must reside in the same directory as the key database file, have the same file naem as the key database file, and have the .sth file extension. For example, if the key database file is MQkeys.pem or MQkeys.kidb , the stash file must be MQkeys.sth .
If these file are not on the appliance, upload or fetch them.

property.name: PermitInsecureServers
property.display: Permit Connections to Insecure SSL Servers When SSL Key Repository is used
property.description: When using SSL Key Repository, specifies whether to permit connections to IBM MQ servers that do not support RFC 5746. Such servers are vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as documented in CVE-2009-3555. The default is off which means reject insecure connections during the SSL handshake.

property.name: PermitSSLv3
property.description: When using SSL Key Repository, specifies whether to allow SSL v3 cipher to be used. The default is off which means no SSL v3 Cipher allowed.

property.name: SSLcipher
property.summary: Cipher suite

description.p: Select the cipher suite for SSL communication when using an SSL key repository. The cipher suite must match the ciphers in use by the IBM MQ Queue Manager.
Use this property with the SSL Key Repository property to enable SSL communication when the SSL artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit).
Note: To integrate with IBM MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the SSL Client Profile property.

property.name: SSLProxyProfile
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL client profile.

description.p: Select an SSL Proxy Profile.

The following table maps the relationship between the SSL Cipher Specification property and the setting required on the Crypto Profile of the SSL Proxy Profile that is assigned to the IBM MQ Queue Manager. Use this information when configuring the SSL Proxy Profile to communicate with the IBM MQ Queue Manager.

property.name: AutoRecovery
property.summary: Advanced recovery after critical error.

property.name: ConvertInput
property.summary: Enable conversion of the incoming message to the default CCSI

description.p: Indicates whether the queue manager can convert input messages to a different CCSI (Coded Character Set Identifier) than the one in the incoming message. This conversion is done by the remote queue manager, not the DataPower device.
Click off to disable automatic conversion of incoming messages to the CCSI established for this IBM MQ Queue Manager.

property.name: AutoRetry
property.summary: Advanced recovery after critical error

description.p: Define whether to attempt to reconnect to remote server after a connection failure. When set to on , the DataPower appliance automatically attempt to reconnect to the remote host. This is on by default.
Note: This setting does not affect attempts to put or get messages over an established connection.

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Specify the time interval (in seconds) between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.

description.p: Specify the time interval (in seconds) between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.
Note: This setting does not affect attempts to PUT or GET messages over an established connection.

property.name: RetryAttempts
property.summary: The number of attempts to retry the failed connections

description.p: Specify the number of attempts to retry the failed connections. After the number of attempts is reached, the Long Retry Interval will be used instead.
Note: 0 (zero) would mean the Long Retry Interval will not be used and will retry forever using Retry Interval.

property.name: LongRetryInterval
property.summary: Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections

description.p: Specify the retry interval to use after the number of short retry attempts is reached. Enter an integer of 0 - 65535 seconds. The default value is 1800.
Note: The Long Retry Interval should be greater than the Retry Interval or it will take no effect.

property.name: ReportingInterval
property.summary: Log a connection failure as an error at this interval
property.description: Specify the number of seconds between the creations of log messages at the error level when failed connections are retried. This setting filters the generation of identical error messages to IBM MQ logging targets.

property.name: AlternateUser
property.summary: Enables ALTERNATE_USER_AUTHORITY flag

description.p: Determines whether to use the MQOD.AlternateUserId as the value of the User Name property.
When enabled (on), uses MQOD.AlternateUserId . When disabled, uses MQMD.UserIdentifier .

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local address for channel

description.p: Specify the local address for outbound connections to a specific local interface and port. Supported formats are 1.1.1.1 or 1.1.1.1(1) or just (1) to tell TCP to bind to port 1 and for a range of ports use (1,10) or 1.1.1.1(1,10).
Note: If the port is set, the range must be greater than the total number of allowed connections.

property.name: PollingTolerance
property.summary: The extra network tolerance time that is added to the polling interval of IBM MQ MQGET call

description.p: Adds the extra network tolerance time to the polling interval of IBM MQ MQGET call
Note: Big tolerance value might impact performance if the transaction is hold to wait MQGET reply from IBM MQ Server

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: XML Manager
property.description: Select an XML Manager.

property.name: SSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between the appliance and its targets
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between the appliance and its targets.

property.name: SSLClient
property.summary: Set the SSL client profile to secure connections between the appliance and its targets
property.description: The SSL client profile to secure connections between the appliance and its targets.

property-group.name: secure
property-group.on-glass:
Secure communication with the remote queue manager in one of two ways. If both, SSL client profile takes precedence.
With an SSL client profile: Specify the SSL client profile. Must use this method for IBM MQ for z/OS.
With artifacts from GSKit: Specify the SSL key repository and cipher specification.

object.description: In IBM MQ, distributed send and receive queues are managed by a component called a queue manager. The queue manager provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager. This Queue Manager object on the device corresponds to a Queue Manager running on another host on the network. The properties set here enable communication between the device and the Queue Manager.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: PrimaryQueueManager
property.description: Specify a queue manager to serve as the primary queue manager for this group. All connections for this group will go to the designated queue manager. If the primary queue manager becomes unavailable, the appliance will use an available backup IBM MQ queue manager.

property.name: BackupQueueManagers
property.description: Specify one or more queue managers to provide redundancy if the primary queue manager becomes unavailable.

description.p: An IBM MQ Queue Manager Group enables automatic failover between queue managers when one (or more) queue manager becomes unavailable.

If you define multiple backup queue managers, the appliance searches in the order in which the queue managers are listed. The first active queue manager in the group replaces the primary queue manager.

Note: In IBM MQ server 7.0.1 or later, you can configure the IBM MQ Queue Manager to work with the multi-instance feature in the IBM MQ server. Connect the primary queue manager to one of the instances of a queue manager in the IBM MQ server, and the backup queue manager to the other instance. All connections for the IBM MQ Queue Manager group in the DataPower appliance will go to the queue manager connected to the active instance. If the active instance in the IBM MQ server fails, the queue manager connected to the standby instance will automatically take over all the data and logs from the queue manager connected to the original active instance.

object.name: MTOMPolicy

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Mode
property.summary: MTOM Mode
property.description:
Specify the optimization mode.
The encode option optimizes (serializes) input messages. For serialization, provide an XPath expression or a list of XPath expressions to identify the content to extract. Optionally, per XPath expression, exercise control over the Content Type and Content ID values. These two values can be determined automatically using the xmlmime:contentType declaration and namespace declaration.
The decode option decodes (deserializes) attachment parts of an optimized message. Deserialization, by default, reassembles the original infoset, which results in either a SOAP document or MIME document depending on whether all attachments were referenced by <Include/> elements. Optionally, you can specify a Content ID to select individual attachment parts to reassemble.

property.name: IncludeContentType
property.summary: Include Content Type Attribute

description.p: Select whether to include the xmlmine:contentType declaration in output messages when the input message does not contain this declaration. If the input message contains this declaration, the MTOM policy passes through the attribute regardless of the setting for this property.

ul.li: Select "on", the default value, to add the contentType declaration to the output message.
Select "off" to not add the contentType declaration to the output message.

property.name: Rule
property.summary: MTOM Rules
property.description: Each MTOM rule describes which message elements to optimize. A single XPath expression selects one or more elements for optimization.

object.description: An MTOM policy provides a mechanism for optimizing the transmission and wire format of an XML/SOAP message. Optimization is performed by selecting elements with base64-encoded character data. The selected elements are decoded and attached as MIME attachment parts before transmission. Decoding before transmission reduces the overhead that is associated with base64-encoded data.

object.name: NameValueProfile

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: MaxAttributes
property.summary: Maximum Number of Name/Value Pairs
property.description: The maximum number of name value pairs allowed in a single entity (header, cookie set, body, and so forth).

property.name: MaxAggregateSize
property.summary: Maximum total size of name value submission
property.description: The lengths of all the names and values in a single entity (header, cookie set, body, query string, and so forth) in aggregate must not exceed this property.

property.name: MaxNameSize
property.summary: Maximum length of an individual name
property.description: The maximum size of a name attribute used in this profile.

property.name: MaxValueSize
property.summary: Maximum length of an individual value
property.description: The maximum size of a value attribute used in this profile.

property.name: ValidationList
property.summary: Validations Specification List
property.description: Each pair submitted to this profile consults this validation list, looking for the first regular expression match of the name against the name expression in the list. When that is found, the corresponding value constraint is matched against the value portion of the name-value pair. If that does not match, the policy applies the 'fixup' attribute to the submitted value. That may result in no change, the pair being removed, an error being generated, or the value being mapped to a known constant.

property.name: DefaultFixup
property.summary: Policy for names that are in validation list
property.description: Select the action to taken when no matching entry in the validation list is found. The default is Strip.

property.name: DefaultMapValue
property.summary: Map unmatched value to this constant
property.description: An value that does not have a matching entry in the validation list is changed to this value if the no match policy is 'set'.

property.name: DefaultXSS
property.summary: Check the value for Cross Site Scripting signatures on values without a validation entry
property.description: This property allows the value to be checked for Cross Site Scripting (XSS) signatures. These signatures are malicious attempts to input client-side script as the input to a web application. If this client-side script is later displayed in a browser, the script executes and can perform malicious activities. Enable this feature to filter input for malicious content that might get stored and displayed again later, such as the contents of a comment form. The check looks for invalid characters and various forms of the term <script that is often used to engage JavaScript on a browser without the user knowing.

property.name: NoMatchXSSPatternsFile
property.display: XSS (Cross Site Scripting) Protection Patterns File
property.summary: XSS (Cross Site Scripting) Protection Patterns File
property.description: Specifies the patterns file that will be used by the XSS filter when No Match XSS is selected. The default file, store:///XSS-Patterns.xml, checks for invalid characters and various forms of the term <script. Specify a custom XML patterns file with PCRE patterns to be used by the XSS filter.

object.description: Many HTTP things are expressed as name value pairs. These include HTTP headers, cookie values, url-encoded query strings, and url-encoded request messages. This profile provides a mechanism for what kinds of names are expected and for each kind of name what properties should be enforced on the corresponding values. When a name-value pair is not validated successfully that may generate an error, the pair might be stripped from the transaction, or the value may be mapped to another default value.

object.name: DNSNameService

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: SearchDomains
property.summary: Manage the list of search domains.
property.description: A list of domain names to use as the search criteria to resolve partial host names.

property.name: NameServers
property.summary: Manage the list of DNS servers.
property.description: The list of DNS servers to contact to resolve host names. If you define multiple servers, ensure that the sequence to contact the servers is your preferred order.
property.hoverhelp: Manage the list of DNS servers. If you define multiple servers, ensure that the sequence to contact the servers is your preferred order. To change the sequence, use the up and down arrows to move a server to the wanted position.

property.name: StaticHosts
property.summary: Manage the static host name to IP address map.
property.description: A map of host names to host IP addresses that do not use DNS resolution. Because the local resolver uses a cache, Static hosts do not improve performance.

property.name: IPPreference
property.summary: Set the preferred IP version.
property.description: The preferred IP version to resolve host names. When a host name resolves to both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, this setting determines which version to use.

property.name: ForceIPPreference
property.summary: Indicate whether to restrict DNS queries to the preferred IP version.
property.description: Whether to restrict DNS queries to the preferred IP version to resolve host names. You want to force the IP preference except when both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are in use. When not forced, the appliance resolves each host name by querying A and AAAA records and waiting for both responses or a timeout. Waiting for the response or timeout for both records can introduce unnecessary latency in DNS resolution.

property.name: LoadBalanceAlgorithm
property.summary: Set the load balancing algorithm.
property.description: The load balancing algorithm to use to resolve host names. The default algorithm is round robin.

property.name: MaxRetries
property.summary: Set the maximum number of resolution attempts.
property.description: For the first alive algorithm, the maximum number of times to send a query to the list of name servers before an error is returned. By default, an unacknowledged resolution request is attempted 3 times.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Set the response timer.
property.description: For the first alive algorithm, the time that the resolver waits for a response from a DNS server. After expiry, the resolver attempts the query to a different DNS server. The default value is 5.

object.description: Configure the DNS name resolution service

object.name: HostAlias

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Enter the local IP address that corresponds to the alias.
property.description: The local IP address that corresponds to the alias.

object.summary: Host aliases allow services that bind to a particular local IP address to use the alias for the binding.
object.description: A host alias is a map between a local IP address to a local alias. The host alias is resolved like a static host entry. Host aliases provide a level of abstraction between concrete network addresses and configuration. You can use host aliases where you can define local IP addresses. Host aliases ease the export and migration of service among DataPower appliances. The alias is exported, but the alias map is not. If the alias is defined on the destination system, the alias resolves to the IP address that is defined on the destination system.

object.name: NetworkSettings

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: BlockNonmanagementTraffic
property.display: Block nonmanagement traffic for invalid interface configuration
property.summary: Indicate whether to block nonmanagement traffic for invalid interface configuration.

description.p: When at least one network interface has an invalid configuration, whether to block nonmanagement traffic or allow all network traffic.

ul.li: When enabled, the appliance blocks nonmanagement traffic.
When disabled, the appliance allows all network traffic.

description.p: For a production appliance, always enable this property. With this setting, the appliance supports only management traffic over Telnet, SSH, web management interfaces (WebGUI and Blueprint Console), and the XML management interface. Until you correct the problem, the appliance cannot accept and process client requests.

hoverhelp.p: When at least one network interface has an invalid configuration, indicate whether to block nonmanagement traffic or allow all network traffic.

ul.li: When enabled, the appliance blocks nonmanagement traffic.
When disabled, the appliance allows all network traffic.

hoverhelp.p: For a production appliance, always enable this property. With this setting, the appliance supports only management traffic over Telnet, SSH, web management interfaces (WebGUI and Blueprint Console), and the XML management interface. Until you correct the problem, the appliance cannot accept and process client requests.

property.name: ICMPDisable
property.summary: Indicate which ICMP replies to disable.
property.description: Which Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) requests to disable the generation of ICMP reply messages.

property.name: ECNDisable
property.summary: Indicate whether to disable ECN TCP indication.
property.description: Whether to disable the generation of ECN-capable TCP sessions. By default, TCP sessions are ECN enabled.

property.name: DestinationRouting
property.summary: Indicate how the appliance determines the route to return the response to the originating client.

description.p: How the appliance determines the route to return the response to the originating client. The route to return the response is the outbound packet. The originating client is the destination of the outbound packet.

ul.li:
When enabled, interface selection is based on the best path to the client, irrespective of the service or receiving interface. The best path is determined by static routes that are bound to the available interfaces.
Note: Destination-based routing is for compatibility with an earlier version only. Enable destination-based routing only if an upgrade disables existing connectivity.

When disabled, the default, interface selection is based on the interface that is bound to the address of the service that generated the response.
If the service is bound to a single address, responses are routed through the interface that is assigned to that address.
If the service is bound to multiple addresses, responses are routed through the receiving interface instead of the interface for the service that generated the response.

hoverhelp.p: Indicate how the appliance determines the route to return the response to the originating client. Enable destination-based routing only if an upgrade disables existing connectivity.

ul.li: When enabled, interface selection is based on the best path to the client, irrespective of the service or receiving interface.
When disabled, interface selection is based on the interface that is bound to the address of the service that generated the response.

property.name: AllowCrosstalkOnSubnet
property.summary: Indicate whether to allow packets from a wrong interface when both interfaces are on the same subnet.
property.description: Whether to relax the restriction on interface isolation. As a security policy, the interface that receives a packet must be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling this option relaxes that restriction. The packet is allowed if the interface it arrives on contains an IP address in the same subnet as the destination address of the packet. Relax interface isolation when destination-routing is enabled.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to allow packets from a wrong interface when both interfaces are on the same subnet. Relax interface isolation when destination-routing is enabled.

property.name: AllowAllCrosstalk
property.summary: Indicate whether to allow packets from one interface that are destined for a service on another interface.
property.description: Whether to allow interface isolation. By default the appliance refuses to accept a packet on an interface other than the one bound to the destination address of the packet. As a security policy, the interface that receives a packet must be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling interface isolation relaxes the restriction.

property.name: TCPSYNRetries
property.summary: Set the number of times to send a failed TCP SYN request.
property.description: The number of times the local system attempts to send a TCP SYN that receives no response. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32. The default value is 5.
property.hoverhelp: Set the number of times the local system attempts to send a TCP SYN that receives no response. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32.

property.name: ArpRetries
property.summary: Set the number of times to attempt a failed ARP request.
property.description: The number of times that the appliance attempts a failed ARP request. Enter a value in the range 1 - 64. The default value is 8.
property.hoverhelp: Set the number of times that the appliance attempts a failed ARP request. Enter a value in the range 1 - 64.

property.name: ArpInterval
property.summary: Set the interval between ARP attempts.
property.description: The interval between ARP attempts. The appliance waits the defined time before it tries a failed ARP request again. Enter a value in the range 500 - 5000. The default value is 500.
property.hoverhelp: Set the interval between ARP attempts. The appliance waits the defined time before it tries a failed ARP request again. Enter a value in the range 500 - 5000.

property.name: TCPSegmentationOffload
property.display: NONTRANSLATABLE - TCP segmentation offload on Ethernet
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE - Whether Ethernet devices perform TCP segmentation offload
property.description: NONTRANSLATABLE - Control whether Ethernet devices perform TCP segmentation offload (TSO). By default, all of the Ethernet device drivers and chips are allowed to perform TSO. This Ethernet chip feature improves performance on large TCP writes to the network. On rare occasions, this feature might interact poorly on a deployed network by causing link layer resets. This option allows disabling TSO on all Ethernet interfaces. Disable this only if customer support has diagnosed that you are encountering this problem. After re-enabling TSO, it is necessary to restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

property.name: ReversePathFiltering
property.summary: Indicate whether to ignore incoming packets with a source address that the interface cannot route.

description.p: Whether incoming packets with a source address that cannot be routed by that interface are accepted and processed. Enabling this option effectively disables source routing because the appliance ignores such packets.

ul.li: When enabled, the interface ignores incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.
When disabled, the default, the interface accepts and processes incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.

hoverhelp.p: Indicate whether to ignore incoming packets with a source address that the interface cannot route.

ul.li: When enabled, the interface ignores incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.
When disabled, the interface accepts and processes incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.

property.name: TCPWindowScaling
property.summary: Indicate whether to enable TCP window scaling.
property.description: Whether to enable TCP window scaling. Window scaling allows the negotiation of window sizes greater than 64 KB. Disabling this option might help to work around TCP systems that do not understand or misinterpret window scaling.
property.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to enable TCP window scaling. Window scaling allows the negotiation of window sizes greater than 64 KB. Disabling this option might help to work around TCP systems that do not understand or misinterpret window scaling.

property.name: StandbyControlMacTakeover
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE - Whether to use virtual MAC address takeover

description.p: NONTRANSLATABLE - Control, in the event of a standby control group takeover, whether to use virtual MAC address takeover. This option is relevant for appliances that are members of a standby control group. When enabled, a standby control takeover moves the group-defined virtual MAC address to the newly active appliance. When disabled, all standby control groups use ARP takeover.
Attention: Do not use this option for any appliance that is active in a standby group.

Before DataPower version 4.0.2, only virtual MAC address takeover is available. Therefore, MAC address takeover must be enabled for compatibility with earlier versions. For new deployments, the default is preferred because it does not require that the network support rapid spanning tree, and takeovers can occur more quickly. However, when MAC address takeover is disabled, stations on the local network must permit and honor gratuitous ARP for a standby control takeover to be effective.

property.name: EphemeralPortRange
property.summary: Set the starting port for the ephemeral port range.
property.description: The starting port of the ephemeral port range. The appliance can use ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 61000 to send data over TCP and UDP. You can define a subset of ephemeral ports to not be ephemeral ports. These ports are ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 32768. The appliance always has control of the ephemeral ports in the range 32769 - 61000.
property.hoverhelp: Set the starting port of the ephemeral port range. The appliance can use ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 61000 to send data over TCP and UDP. You can define a subset of ephemeral ports to not be ephemeral ports. These ports are ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 32768. The appliance always has control of the ephemeral ports in the range 32769 - 61000.

object.description: Configure appliance-wide network settings.

object.name: NTPService

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: Mode
property.summary: NONTRANSLATABLE
property.description: NONTRANSLATABLE

property.name: RemoteServer
property.summary: Enter the host name or IP address of the NTP server.
property.description: The host name or IP address of an NTP server. If you define multiple servers, ensure that the sequence to contact the servers is your preferred order.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the host name or IP address of the NTP server. If you define multiple servers, ensure that the sequence to contact the servers is your preferred order. To change the sequence, place the cursor over the entry to move and drag it to the wanted position.

property.name: RefreshInterval
property.summary: Modify the interval between clock synchronizations.
property.description: The interval between clock synchronizations. Enter a value in the range 60 - 86400. The default value is 900.
property.hoverhelp: Modify the interval between clock synchronizations. Enter a value in the range 60 - 86400.

object.description: Configure remote NTP (Network Time Protocol) server. This allows the automatic synchronization of the system clock.

object.name: NFSClientSettings

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: MountRefreshTime
property.summary: Time between NFS mount revalidations.
property.description: The status of each NFS mount is checked at this interval. This is done to quickly detect NFS servers that are down, so that there will not be application-level NFS timeouts waiting for them. This is also how often they are checked when they are down, trying to bring them back up.

object.description: Use this page to configure global NFS client parameters. This is the global configuration for enabling NFS.

object.name: NFSDynamicMounts

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Version
property.summary: Preferred NFS protocol version for dynamic NFS mounts.
property.description: Preferred NFS protocol version for dynamic NFS mounts. If the Version is 3, but the server only implements Version 2, the client will fall back to Version 2. But if the Version is 4, there is no fallback, since the remote export paths are not the same.

property.name: Transport
property.summary: Starting transport protocol
property.description: Transport protocol to start with for dynamic NFS mounts. If TCP is selected and it is not available on the NFS server, UDP will be used instead. When NFS version 4 is selected, this option is ignored and always defaults to TCP.

property.name: MountType
property.summary: Type of NFS mount to use
property.description: Select the type of NFS mount to use. The default behavior is to use NFS hard mounts, which is generally the appropriate behavior.

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Allow only file reads on dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: ReadSize
property.summary: Size of read operations for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: WriteSize
property.summary: Size of write operations for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Time until first retransmission is sent on an RPC timeout, for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: Retransmissions
property.summary: Number of minor RPC timeouts and retransmissions until major timeout, for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: IdleUnmountSeconds
property.summary: How many seconds an dynamic NFS mount will be left mounted with no file activity until it gets unmounted. Setting it to 0 disables automatic unmounting.

property.name: MountTimeoutSeconds
property.summary: How many seconds the system will attempt to retry a dynamic NFS mount until it gives up, and causes the related file open(s) to fail.

object.description: Use this page to configure the parameters of dynamic NFS mounts for dpnfs: URL fetches. These mounts support access via URLs of the form dpnfs://hostname/path/file, causing the directory hostname:/path to be automatically mounted by NFS. It remains mounted until it times out for inactivity.

object.name: NFSStaticMount

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: remote
property.summary: Exported NFS file system to mount.
property.description: Specifies remote NFS-exported filesystem to mount. In the form host:/path, where host is the DNS name or IP address of the NFS server, and path is the path exported by the host to mount.

property.name: LocalFilesystemAccess
property.summary: Allow local filesystem access through folder nfs-name:.
property.description: If enabled, makes the NFS mount available for filesystem access through the command line interface, under the folder name nfs- mountName , where mountName is the name of this mount.

property.name: Version
property.summary: Preferred version of NFS protocol to use.
property.description: Preferred NFS protocol version for this mount. If the Version is 3, but the server only implements Version 2, the client will fall back to Version 2. But if the Version is 4, there is no fallback, since the remote export paths are not the same.

property.name: Transport
property.summary: Starting transport protocol
property.description: Select the transport protocol to start with. For NFS versions 2 and 3, if TCP is selected and it is not available on the NFS server, UDP will be used instead. When NFS version 4 is selected, this option is ignored and always defaults to TCP.

property.name: MountType
property.summary: Type of NFS mount to use
property.description: Select the type of NFS mount to use. The default behavior is to use NFS hard mounts, which is generally the appropriate behavior.

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Allow only file reads on this mount.

property.name: ReadSize
property.summary: Size of NFS read operations.

property.name: WriteSize
property.summary: Size of NFS write operations.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Time until first retransmission on RPC timeout.

property.name: Retransmissions
property.summary: Number of minor RPC timeouts and retransmissions until major timeout.

object.description: Use this page to create a static NFS mount, for URL or filesystem access. These mounts will be kept mounted whenever their application domain is up.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Contains a brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: ODRConnectorGroups
property.summary: Connector Groups
property.description: Define one ODR connector group for each WebSphere cell. Each connector group establishes the communications with an Intelligent management service in that cell. The appliance retrieves topology information, application information, routing rules, and other information over the connectors in the connector group.

property.name: ODRCustomProperties
property.summary: Custom Properties
property.description: The ODR custom properties can augment the current configuration. Follow the documentation explicitly to use a custom property.

description.p: Specifies an on demand router (ODR). The ODR feature acts as a collection of load balancer groups that distribute traffic to various clusters within a WebSphere cell. If multiple ODR connector groups are defined, the ODR distributes traffic to any of the clusters within any of the cells.
The ODR feature on the appliance supports a subset of On Demand Router in Intelligent Management, WebSphere Application Server, Network Deployment.

object.name: ODRConnectorGroup

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Contains a brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: ODRGroupConnectors
property.summary: Connectors that are used to retrieve ODR information
property.description: An ODR connector defines a connection to the Intelligent management service. The appliance retrieves topology, weights, session affinity, and other information from the WebSphere cell over the connection. If multiple connectors are configured, the top most connection is tried first, followed by the second, and so on. Once a connection is established, other endpoints might be retrieved and used if the configured connector endpoint is down. You must define at least one connector in an ODR connector group. You cannot define more than 16 connectors.

property.name: SSLProxy

object.name: PasswordAlias

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: Password
property.summary: Enter the plaintext password to alias
property.description: The plaintext password to alias.

object.summary: Manage the mapping of aliases to passwords

description.p: The Password Map Alias provides the mapping of an alias to a plaintext password. The alias is a publicly known reference that is included in configuration files and exports. With an alias you keep the real password secret because the plaintext value for the password is stored in an encrypted file. The password for the alias cannot be viewed or accessed by anyone. Only the appliance can extract the password that it uses internally.

No passwords that are aliased are written to configuration files. The mapping of aliases to passwords is not part of a backup or export operation, but it is part of the secure backup-restore operations.

property.name: AliasPairs
property.summary: Alias-to-password entry that links an alias to a password
property.description: The alias-to-password entry that links an alias to a password.

description.p: The Password Map, also known as a password-to-alias map, provides the mapping of aliases to passwords. The alias is a publicly known reference that is included in configuration files and exports. With an alias you keep the real password secret because the plaintext value for the password is stored in an encrypted file. The password for the alias cannot be viewed or accessed by anyone. Only the appliance can extract the password that it uses internally.
No passwords in a map are written to configuration files. The password-to-alias map is not part of a backup or export operation, but it is part of the secure backup-restore operations.

object.name: PeerGroup

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: Type
property.summary: Type of peer group
property.description: The type of peer group that exchange data.

property.name: URL
property.summary: URL of peer

description.p: The URL of each peer in the protocol://address:port format for an Ethernet interface or a VLAN interface. For unicast peering, peers exchange SLM data over the XML management interface as SOAP over HTTPS. Multicast peering shares the initial SLM state using SOAP over HTTPS; the data transfers are done using multicast.
The default port for the XML Management Interface is 5550. If this port is changed on any peer, the URL must reflect the correct port.
When defining the collection of peers, include all peers, including the local appliance.

property.name: IPMulticast
property.summary: IP Multicast
property.description: An IP Multicast object that handles the underlying transmission of packets used for data exchange between the peers.

property.name: UpdateInterval
property.summary: Update Interval
property.description: The time interval in milliseconds that data is transmitted between the peers.

object.description: A collection of appliances that automatically update each other with real time data of the types selected. For example, members in the group exchange data to allow the enforcement of a policy across the collection.
