property.summary: Provides a link to the DataPower Enterprise Configuration MIB.

property.name: StatusMib
property.summary: Provides a link to the DataPower Enterprise Status MIB.

property.name: NotifMib
property.summary: Provides a link to the DataPower Enterprise Notification MIB.

object.description: Use this page to establish SNMP connectivity to the device, and to set values used by SNMP.

object.name: AS2ProxySourceProtocolHandler

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Enter the IP address or host alias on which the service listens.
property.description: Specifies the address to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. The default value indicates that the service listens on all IP addresses.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the IP address or host alias to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. The default value indicates that the service listens on all IP addresses.
property.label: IP address

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: Specifies the port to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 80.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the port to listen on for incoming HTTP traffic. Enter a value in the range of 1 - 65535. The default value is 80.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.summary: HTTP version for client side connections
property.description: Select the HTTP version for client side connections. The default value is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Methods and versions to allow for incoming requests
property.description: Specifies the methods and versions to allow for incoming HTTP requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Whether to negotiate persistent connections on front side
property.description: Indicates whether to negotiate persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: MaxPersistentConnectionsReuse
property.summary: The maximum number of times a persistent connection is reused on the front side
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of times a persistent connection is reused on the front side. When the maximum reuse count is reached, an explicit HTTP Connection: close header is sent in the response and the TCP connection is closed. The default value is 0, which means unlimited reuse.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Indicate whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.

description.p: Whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.
If enabled, the DataPower service uses GZIP to compress HTTP transmissions when the Accept-Encoding HTTP header indicates that compressed documents can be processed.
The Transfer-Encoding HTTP header indicates compression.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The length of the longest incoming URL to accept
property.description: Specifies the length of the longest incoming URL to accept. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier. Enter a value in the range 1 - 128000. The default value is 16384.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum aggregate length of incoming HTTP headers to allow
property.description: Specifies the maximum aggregate length of incoming HTTP headers to allow. Enter a value in the range 5 - 128000. The default value is 128000.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.summary: Maximum number of headers to allow in HTTP requests
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of headers to allow in the incoming request messages. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum length of the name part of an HTTP header
property.description: Specifies the maximum length of HTTP header names. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting specifies the maximum length of the name portion for HTTP headers. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum length of the value part of an HTTP header
property.description: Specifies the maximum length of HTTP header values to allow. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
property.summary: Maximum length of the HTTP query string to allow
property.description: The portion of the URL after the question mark (?) is known as the query string. This property specifies its maximum length in bytes. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: ACL
property.summary: The access control list to allow or deny access to this service
property.description: Specifies the access control list to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an access control list denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.name: CredentialCharset
property.summary: Character encoding of the original basic authentication values
property.description: Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The appliance transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. The default value is Protocol, which represents ISO-8859-1, Latin 1.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL server profile or SSL SNI server profile.
property.description: Specifies an SSL proxy profile for securing the communication between the requesting client and the appliance.
property.label: SSL proxy profile

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.summary: IP address, host name, or load balancer group name of the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.
property.description: Specifies the IP address, host name, or name of a load balancer group of the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: RemotePort
property.summary: Destination port on the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.
property.description: Specifies the destination port on the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: RemoteSSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL client profile.

description.p: Specifies an SSL proxy profile for securing the communication between the DataPower appliance and the remote Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: RemoteConnectionTimeout
property.summary: Connection timeout
property.description: Specifies the number of seconds that the appliance waits to establish a connection to the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 86400. The default value is 60.

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: An XML manager
property.description: Specifies an existing XML manager. An XML manager obtains and manages XML documents, style sheets, and other document resources on behalf of one or more services.

property.name: EnablePassthrough
property.summary: Whether to pass the original AS2 requests to Multi-Protocol Gateway processing policy
property.description:
Controls whether to pass the original AS2 requests to the processing policy of Multi-Protocol Gateway.
When enabled, the AS2 proxy handler passes the original AS2 requests to Multi-Protocol Gateway processing policy.
When disabled, the AS2 proxy handler first uses the cryptographic information in the partner exchange profile to decrypt the incoming AS2 requests and verify the signature. The AS2 proxy handler then passes the decrypted request body with signature removed to Multi-Protocol Gateway for processing.

property.name: EnableVisibilityEvent
property.summary: Whether to send visibility events to the MEIG visibility event endpoint
property.description: Controls whether to send the visibility events generated by the AS2 proxy handler to the MEIG visibility event endpoint. These visibility events are correlated to those generated by the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server in one transaction thread.

property.name: VisibilityEventEndpoint
property.summary: The location of the MEIG visibility event endpoint
property.description: Specifies the URL of the MEIG visibility event endpoint. Enter the URL in the format of static IBM MQ URL that provides the information about the IBM MQ server name, queue manager name, and name of the channel configured in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server. For example, dpmq://NAME_OF_MQ_OBJECT/?RequestQueue=QUEUE_NAME_FOR_VISIBILITY_EVENT

property.name: EnableHmacAuthentication
property.summary: Whether to use HMAC to secure visibility event delivery
property.description: Controls whether to use Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) to secure all visibility events sent to the visibility event endpoint. If HMAC is enabled in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server, you must enable HMAC authentication in the AS2 proxy handler to avoid message rejection.

property.name: HmacPassphrase
property.summary: HMAC passphrase
property.description: Specifies the passphrase used to calculate the HMAC token for message authentication and integrity check in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: HmacPassphraseAlias
property.summary: HMAC passphrase alias
property.description: Specifies the password alias of the passphrase used to calculate the HMAC token for message authentication and integrity checking in the Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLClientConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between the DataPower appliance and the remote Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server.

description.p: The SSL profile type to secure connections between the DataPower appliance and the remote Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway server. This communication must be SSL protected. You can define the SSL proxy profile for this communication in one of the following places:

ul.li: Define the SSL profile in the user agent that is assigned to the XML manager for the Multi-Protocol Gateway service.
Define the SSL profile here.

description.p: Ensure that the SSL profile is defined in one of these places. Without the remote SSL profile, processing is stopped and an error is logged.

property.name: SSLClient
property.summary: Set the SSL client profile to secure connections between the appliance and its targets
property.description: The SSL client profile to secure connections between the appliance and its targets.

object.display: MEIG AS2 Proxy Front Side Handler
object.summary: MEIG AS2 Proxy Front Side Handler
object.description: A MEIG AS2 proxy handler receives AS2 requests over HTTP or HTTPS and forwards them to the backend which is assumed to be an IBM Multi-Enterprise Integration Gateway (MEIG) server. AS2 proxy handlers conform to gateway specifications of RFC 2616 and AS2 specification of RFC 4130.

object.name: AS2SourceProtocolHandler

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 80) that specifies the port monitored by the HTTP service.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.summary: Front side HTTP version
property.description: Select the HTTP version to use on the front (client) side connection. The default is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Request methods and versions must be of only the allowed types
property.description: Specifies the allowed methods and versions for incoming HTTP requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Enable/Disable GZIP compression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression functionality on front side.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted
property.description: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted in bytes. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Aggregate Size of Incoming Headers
property.description: The maximum aggregate byte size of incoming HTTP headers.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.display: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.summary: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.description: The maximum number of headers allowed in the request message. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the name portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.description: The portion of the URL after a ? is the query string. This property specifies its maximum length in bytes. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL server profile or SSL SNI server profile.
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the handler.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.name: AAAPolicy
property.description: This AAA Policy will be used to authenticate inbound messages recieved on this frontside protocol handler.

property.name: CredentialCharset
property.summary: Character encoding of the original basic authentication values
property.description: Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The appliance transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. Defaults to Protocol which is ISO-8859-1, Latin 1.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

object.description: The configuration for a front side HTTP protocol handler. This handler receives HTTP requests sent to the device and forwards them to the appropriate gateway. It conforms to gateway specifications of RFC 2616.

object.name: AS3SourceProtocolHandler

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address

description.p: Enter the address on which the FTP server service listens. The default of 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases can help ease migration tasks among machines. If the FTP server service is listening on a virtual IP address managed by a standby control group with the self-balancing feature enabled, incoming control and data connections will always go to the active member of the standby control group.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Local TCP port for the FTP server

description.p: Enter the port that is monitored by the FTP Server service. This port is the port on which FTP control connections can be established. This port does not control the TCP port that is used for the data connections. If the FTP client uses the PASV command, data connections will use an arbitrary, unused TCP port. Defaults to 21. Valid range is 1 through 65535.

property.name: FilesystemType
property.summary: The type of filesystem the FTP server will present

description.p: Select the file system type that is presented by the FTP server.

ul.li: If Virtual Ephemeral or Virtual Persistent is chosen, the client can write files to all directories. These files are shown in directory listings but cannot be retrieved. For file system responses, the responses are shown and can be retrieved, renamed, and deleted by the client.
If Transparent is chosen, the file system shows the contents of the equivalent path of the server on the back-end of the Multi-Protocol Gateway with which this FTP server is associated.

description.p: This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: PersistentFilesystemTimeout
property.summary: Controls how long a Virtual Persistent file system with no active connections is retained
property.description: Enter the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all FTP control connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. All of the response files that were not deleted by the FTP client are deleted from their storage area. Default to 600 (10 minutes). Valid range is 1 to 43,200 seconds (12 hours).

property.name: VirtualDirectories
property.summary: Create directory in virtual file system of FTP server
property.description: In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this FTP server. The FTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created. Its response directory is always the root directory.

property.name: DefaultDirectory
property.summary: Default for current working directory
property.description: Enter the initial working directory on the FTP server (after users connect and authenticate). When using a virtual file system and the working directory is not the root directory, the specified directory must be one of the configured virtual directories. The default is the root directory (/).

property.name: MaxFilenameLength
property.summary: Maximum length of a file name on the server
property.description: Enter the maximum file name length on the FTP server. Defaults to 256 characters. Valid range is 1 through 4000.

description.p: Select an Access Control List to apply. The ACL allows or denies access to the FTP server based on the IP address of the FTP client. When attached to a server, the default for an ACL is to deny all access. To deny access to only select IP addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0). Then, create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.name: RequireTLS
property.summary: Control whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption

description.p:
Specify whether FTP control connections require explicit TLS encryption. If required, the following rules apply:
The FTP client must use the FTP AUTH TLS command before any other command.
You must specify an SSL profile to secure connections.
This property does not control encryption of data transfers.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL server profile or SSL SNI server profile.

description.p: Specify an SSL proxy profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: PasswordAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA policy for validating user name and password

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of user names and passwords provided to the FTP server by the client with the USER and PASS commands. If the authentication succeeds, the FTP client may use all the features of the FTP server. If the authentication fails, a 530 error is returned, and the user can attempt to authenticate again. Without this AAA Policy configured, any user name and password will be accepted.

property.name: CertificateAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA Policy for determining whether password is required

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform secondary authentication of the information provided in the TLS/SSL certificate provided during TLS negotiation after the AUTH TLS command to the FTP server. Primary authentication is done by the SSL Profile, it can completely reject a certificate. This authentication stage controls whether an FTP password will be demanded or not. If the result of this authentication succeeds, the FTP client will only have to use the USER command to login after the AUTH TLS. If this authentication fails, the FTP client will have to use both the USER and PASS commands to complete the login process. If no Certificate AAA Policy is configured, USER and PASS will always be required. If the AUTH TLS command is not used by the FTP client, USER and PASS will always be required.

property.name: AllowCCC
property.summary: Control use of CCC command

description.p: Specify whether the FTP CCC command can be used to turn off TLS encryption of the FTP control connection after user authentication. If allowed, the CCC command can be used to turn off encryption after authentication. Turning off encryption is necessary when the FTP control connection crosses a firewall or NAT device that needs to sniff the control connection. Turning off encryption eliminates the secrecy of the files being transferred and allows TCP packets injection attacks.

property.name: Passive
property.summary: Control use of passive mode
property.description: Control use of the FTP PASV and EPSV commands by the FTP client, as an alternative to the PORT and EPRT commands. The default is to allow PORT, EPRT, PASV, and EPSV. Other settings either require PASV or EPSV, or require PORT or EPRT. If an acceptable PORT, EPRT, PASV, or EPSV command is not received, the STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, and NLST data transfer commands will fail. (This FTP server will never attempt to connect to the deprecated default FTP data port at TCP port 20.)

property.name: UsePasvPortRange
property.display: Limit Port Range for Passive Connections
property.summary: Enable using a limited range of TCP port numbers for Passive connections.

description.p: When enabled, when a PASV or EPSV command is received from the FTP client, instead of selecting any free listening TCP port in the range 1024 to 65534, allow configuration of a restricted port range. This may be used when a firewall wants to allow incoming FTP data connections only on a limited range of ports, particularly when it cannot "sniff" the FTP control connection.

Note that the size of the range specified limits how many FTP clients can be in the state between receiving the 227 response code to the PASV or EPSV command, and establishing the FTP data TCP connection. Pressure on this limited resource can be controlled by adjusting the passive data connection idle timeout.

While it is perfectly legal to configure multiple FTP servers on the same system to use the same (or overlapping) passive port ranges, realize that they are contending for a common resource in the TCP implementation.

However, it is not wise to use a port range that overlaps with other services (HTTP servers, etc.) that are configured on the system. There is no configuration checking for such conflicts, and other configured services will allocate the ports first, and they will not be available for the FTP server. (The FTP server allocates these listening ports dynamically.)

property.name: PasvMinPort
property.summary: Lowest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the lowest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not greater than Maximum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvMaxPort
property.summary: Highest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the highest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not less than Minimum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvIdleTimeOut
property.summary: Idle timeout for a passive data connection

description.p: Specifies the number of seconds that the server waits for a client to establish a passive connection. Use an integer in the range of 5 through 300. The default is 60.

This setting controls the amount of time in seconds between when the FTP server issues code 227 (Entering Passive Mode) in response to the PASV or EPSV command from the FTP client and when the FTP client must establish a TCP data connection to the listening port and issue a data transfer command.

ul.li: If the data connection is not established within the timeout period, the listening port will be closed. If a data transfer command is issued after the port is closed, the command fails with code 425 and the Failed to open data connection message.

If the data connection is established but no data transfer command is issued within the timeout period, the TCP data connection will be closed. Any data transfer command after the timeout will be treated as if the PASV or EPSV command was never issued. The command fails with code 425 and the Require PASV or PORT command first message.

property.name: DisablePASVIPCheck
property.display: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check
property.summary: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check

description.p: This option will disable the IP security check that is done when processing the FTP PASV command. The check verifies that the IP address of the client connecting to the data connection is the same as the one that established the control connection.

The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server. Turn the option on if there is a specific reason the incoming connection will not be coming from the same client as the control connection (i.e. from a load balancer).
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: DisablePORTIPCheck
property.display: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check
property.summary: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check

description.p: This option will disable the IP security check that verifies that outgoing data connections can only connect to the client.
The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server.
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: UseAlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Use Alternate PASV IP Address

description.p: When on, this option will enable the ability to override the IP address that is presented to the FTP client when the server is in passive mode.
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: AlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Alternate PASV IP Address

description.p: The numeric IP address that will be returned to the FTP client in response to a PASV command. This does not change the IP address that the FTP server will listen on, which is always the IP address that the FTP data connection was made to. This is used in certain situations when the FTP server is behind a firewall that is not FTP-aware.

property.name: AllowLISTCmd
property.summary: Enable LIST command support

description.p: When on, the server will make a distinction between the LIST and NLST commands. When off, the server will always respond with an NLST when requesting a file listing.
The default value for this option is off
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: AllowDELECmd
property.summary: Enable DELE (delete) support

description.p: When on, allows the DELE (delete) command to be passed to the FTP back-end server. This is only valid in Transparent Filesystem type.
The default value for this option is off
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: DataEncryption
property.summary: Control use of data encryption for file transfers
property.description: Select the use of encryption for data connections (file transfers). Data encryption is controlled by the FTP PROT P command.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Control use of MODE Z command to compress data transfer

description.p: Specify whether the FTP client can use FTP MODE Z compression. After enabling FTP compression, the FTP client can use the zlib method to compress data transfers.

property.name: AllowSTOU
property.summary: Control use of STOU command for unique file names

description.p: Specify whether the FTP client can use the FTP STOU command. When enabled, the FTP server generates a unique file name for each transferred file.

property.name: UniqueFilenamePrefix
property.summary: Prefix of all unique filenames generated by STOU

description.p: Enter the prefix (leading characters) for file names that are generated when using the FTP STOU command. When defining the prefix, the directory separator (/) is not allowed. The default is to not add a prefix, which is an empty string.
Note: The software adds a numeric suffix.

property.name: AllowREST
property.summary: Control use of the REST command for interrupted file transfers

description.p: Controls whether the FTP client can use the FTP REST command to continue the transfer of a file after an interruption in the data transfer. This is supported in the BSD stream style described in draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt. (The MODE B style that is described in RFC 959 is not supported.) The FTP server must be configured with a virtual persistent file system.

For written files, the server will delay the actual processing until a timeout expires or until the next FTP command other than a SIZE or REST command. This processing allows the FTP client can return and resume to the transfer using the SIZE, REST, and STOR commands. The argument to the REST command must be the same as the byte count returned by the SIZE command.
Note: The response code to all STOR commands on this server will always be 226. The response codes does not reflect the success of the transaction.
This capability is also supported for reading the response files, if the server is configured for a Response Type of Virtual Filesystem.
Note: The generation of response files are delayed until the transaction is completed.

property.name: RestartTimeout
property.summary: Time that the STOR command waits for a restart

description.p: When restart (REST) is enabled, the number of seconds that the FTP client has to reconnect to the server and use the SIZE, REST, and STOR commands to continue an interrupted file transfer. If this period of time elapses, the data that was received to this point on the TCP data connection will be passed to the Multi-Protocol Gateway. This timeout is canceled if another command (other than SIZE or REST) is received on the FTP control connection.

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Inactivity limit on FTP control connection
property.description: Enter the number of seconds that the FTP control connection can be idle. After the specified duration elapses, the FTP server closes the control connection. Defaults to 0, which disables the timeout.

property.name: ResponseType
property.summary: How to make response available to FTP client
property.description: Select how to make response files available for gateway transactions started by an FTP STOR or SOUT operation.

property.name: ResponseStorage
property.summary: Where to store response files
property.description: Select where response files are stored.

property.name: TemporaryStorageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of temporary file system
property.description: Enter in megabytes the maximum size for the temporary file system size. Defaults to 32 MB. Valid range is 1 MB through 2048 MB.

property.name: ResponseNFSMount
property.summary: NFS mount to store response files in

description.p: When Response Type is Virtual File System and Response Storage is NFS, select an NFS static mount to apply. Each response file will have a unique file name in the NFS directory. The name of the response file is not related to the file name that the virtual file system presents to the FTP client. Generally, this NFS directory is not made available through the FTP server. This directory should not be used for any other purpose.

property.name: ResponseSuffix
property.summary: URL file name suffix to response file
property.description: When the response type is a virtual file system or an FTP client, enter the suffix to add when generating response files. The directory separator (/) is not allowed. If the response type is a virtual file system and the FTP client is writing in virtual directories that do not have a response directory or if the response directory is the same as the virtual directory, this value must have a non-empty value. If empty, the response would try to overwrite the request, which is not allowed. Defaults to an empty string.

property.name: ResponseURL
property.summary: URL for generating a response via FTP client

description.p: When Response Type is FTP Client, enter the URL to use when generating response files. This URL enables a response to be written using FTP commands. The URL must be an FTP URL that starts with ftp:// . The URL should include a directory, but not a file name. The URL cannot include query parameters. The default is to have no response generated (an empty string).

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

object.description: AS3 Front Side Handler

object.name: EBMS2SourceProtocolHandler

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 80) that specifies the port monitored by the HTTP service.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.summary: Front side HTTP version
property.description: Select the HTTP version to use on the front (client) side connection. The default is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Enable/Disable GZIP compression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression functionality on front side.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted
property.description: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted in bytes. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Aggregate Size of Incoming Headers
property.description: The maximum aggregate byte size of incoming HTTP headers.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.display: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.summary: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.description: The maximum number of headers allowed in the request message. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the name portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL server profile or SSL SNI server profile.
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the handler.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.name: AAAPolicy
property.description: This AAA Policy will be used to authenticate inbound messages recieved on this frontside protocol handler.

property.name: CredentialCharset
property.summary: Character encoding of the original basic authentication values
property.description: Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The appliance transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. Defaults to Protocol which is ISO-8859-1, Latin 1.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

object.description: The configuration for a front side ebMS2 protocol handler.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: TargetDirectory
property.summary: The directory to poll.

description.p: Specify the directory to poll. The path must end in a slash. The path denotes a directory.

ul.li:
FTP examples:
Absolute to the root directory: "ftp://user:password@host:port/%2Fpath/"
If the user name or password contains the characters colon (:), at symbol (@), or slash (/), use their URL-encoded values in accordance with the specification.
Relative to the home directory of the user: "ftp://user:password@host:port/path/"
Include a password in the URL with caution. The use of user:/password@host results in a server connection. However, with this configuration, the connection could be unable to send multiple commands to the FTP server. For a stable connection, define a basic authentication policy in the user agent. The user agent is in the XML manager associated with the DataPower service.

NFS example:
"dpnfs://static-mount-name/path/"

SFTP examples:
Absolute to the root directory: "sftp://host:port/path/"
Relative to the home directory of the user: "sftp://host:port/~/path/"

description.p: Do not configure one poller to point at a host name that is a virtual name of a load balancer group. This configuration is not the correct way to poll multiple hosts. To poll multiple hosts, use the same DataPower service and configure one poller object for each real host.

property.hoverhelp: Enter the path of the directory to poll. For example: 'ftp://user:password@host:port/path/'. If the user name or password contains colon (;), at symbol (@), or slash (/), use their URL-encoded values instead. The path must end with a slash.
property.label: Target directory

property.name: DelayBetweenPolls
property.summary: Interval between polling sequences

description.p: Enter the number of milliseconds to wait after the completion of one poll sequence before starting the next one. A polling sequence is the actual polling action plus the time to complete all transactions that were started by the poll action. The next polling action will start the specified number of milliseconds after the last transaction completes.
Enter any value of 25 - 100000000. The default is 60000.

property.name: InputFileMatchPattern
property.summary: File name pattern to base poll search criteria.

description.p: Enter the PCRE to use to match the contents of the directory being polled. If there is file-renaming or there is a response, this PCRE must create PCRE back references using () pairs.
For example, if the input files are NNNNNN.input , the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" .

property.hoverhelp: Enter the Perl Compatible Regular Expressions (PCRE) to use to match the contents of the directory that is polled. If there is file-renaming or there is a response, this PCRE must create PCRE back references using () pairs. For example, if the input files are NNNNNN.input , the match pattern would be '([0-9]{6})\.input$' .
property.label: Input file match pattern

property.name: ProcessingRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that is being processed.

description.p: Enter the PCRE to use to rename a file that is being processed. This functionality allows multiple pollers to poll the same directory with the same match pattern. There is no lack of atomity if the rename operation on the server is atomic. The poller that succeeds in renaming the input file will proceed to process the file. Any other poller that tries to rename the file at the same time will fail to rename the file and will proceed to try the next file that matches the specified match pattern.
To ensure uniqueness, the resulting file name will be in the following format:
filename . hostname . serial . domain . poller . timestamp

dl.dd: The file name for the renamed input file.
The hostname (system identifier) of the configured DataPower device.
The serial number of the configured DataPower device.
The domain of the polling object.
The name of the polling object.
The timestamp

description.p: Note: File renaming cannot be used with an FTP server that supports only 8.3 file names.

For example if the input files are NNNNNN.input and you want to rename them to NNNNNN.processing , then the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the processing pattern would be "$1.processing" . The resultant file name on the server would be:

p.tt: NNNNNN.processing. hostname . serial . domain . poller . timestamp

description.p: Note: If no processing rename pattern is configured, the file will still be renamed. The only difference is that the filename portion of the resulting file is the name of the original input file, not the renamed input file.

property.name: DeleteOnSuccess
property.summary: Delete an input file after successful processing.

description.p: Select whether to delete the input file after successful processing.

ul.li: When on , deletes the input file.
When off , renames the input file using the renaming pattern specified by Success File Renaming Pattern.

property.name: SuccessRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that has been processed successfully.

description.p: When Delete File on Success is off, enter the PCRE to use to rename the input file on success. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are NNNNNN.input and you want to rename them to NNNNNN.processed , the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the rename pattern would be "$1.processed" .

Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be "(.*)" and the rename pattern would be "../processed/$1" .

property.name: DeleteOnError
property.summary: Delete a file after failure to process.

description.p: Select whether to delete the input or processing rename file when it could not be processed.

ul.li: When on , deletes the file.
When off , renames the input or processing rename file using the renaming pattern specified by Error File Renaming Pattern.

property.name: ErrorRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that could not be processed.

description.p: When Delete File on Processing Error is off , enter the PCRE to use to rename a file when it could not be processed.

property.name: GenerateResultFile
property.summary: Create a result file after processing an input file.

description.p: Select whether to create a result file after processing an input file.

ul.li: When on , creates the result file using the naming pattern specified by Result File Name Pattern.
When off , does not create the result file.

property.name: ResultNamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to build the name of a response file.

description.p: When Generate Result File is on, enter the PCRE to use as the match pattern to build the name of the result file. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are NNNNNN.input and the desired result file name is NNNNNN.result , then the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the result pattern would be "$1.result" .

Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be "(.*)" and the result pattern would be "../result/$1" .

property.name: ProcessingSeizeTimeout
property.summary: Time to wait before processing a file that is already in processing state.

description.p: Enter the time to wait, in seconds, before processing a file that is already in the processing state. Enter any value of 0 - 1000. The default is 0 which means disabled.

Processing seize allows failure handling of a poller when multiple data routers are polling the same target. If another data router renames a file and does not process (and rename or delete) it within the specified number of seconds, this system attempts to take over processing. This system will attempt to take over processing when all of these three conditions are met when compared to the processing seize pattern.

ol.li: The base file name (first match phrase) is the processing seize pattern
The host name (second match phrase) is not the name of this system
The timestamp (third match phrase) is further in the past than the wait time specified by this timeout

description.p: When these three conditions are met, this system renames the file (with its host name and fresh timestamp) and locally processes the file. This processing assumes that the rename succeeded.

property.name: ProcessingSeizePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to find files being processed.

description.p: Enter the PCRE to use to find files that were renamed to indicate that they are in the "being processed" state but the processing was never completed.

The processing seize pattern contains three phrases that must be in "()" pairs. The first phrase is the base file name that includes the configured processing suffix. The second phrase is the host name. The third phrase is the timestamp.
For example: "(.*).processing.([^.]*).([0-9]*)" . This assumes that "$1.processing" was supplied as the Processing File Renaming Pattern.

property.name: XMLManager
property.summary: An XML manager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets and documents. The XML Manager can also control the size and depth of messages processed by this host. Specify an existing XML Manager. More than one service may use the same XML Manager.

property.name: MaxTransfersPerPoll
property.display: Maximum File Transfers Per Poll Cycle
property.summary: Maximum Number of Files To Be Transferred During Each Cycle of the Poller Connection

description.p: The number of allowed concurrent client connections in a polling sequence.

Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The value must be less than the number of simultaneous connections that the polled server accepts. The default value is 0 which means unlimited number of connections based on available system resources. To avoid the consumption of all the systems resources, enter a value other than 0.

object.name: FTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler
object.description: Use this front side option to have file based input from a configured FTP directory. The directory must exist and have the appropriate permission to perform the designated operations. For these configured directories, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

object.name: NFSFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler
object.description: Use this front side option to have file based input from an NFS mount. The mount point must exist and have the appropriate permissions to perform the designated operations. For these configured mount points, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

object.name: SFTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler

property.name: SSHClientConnection
property.summary: SSH Client Connection Profile
property.description: Specifies the name of the SSH Client Profile which describes how SSH connections are made from the SSH client to an SSH server.
property.hoverhelp: Specify the name of the SSH Client Profile that describes the authentication type and credentials that are used for the connection from the SSH client to an SSH server.
property.label: SSH client connection

object.description: Use this front side option to have file based input from a configured SFTP directory. The directory must exist and have the appropriate permission to perform the designated operations. For these configured directories, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Brief summary for user annotation.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Local IP address

description.p: Enter the address on which the FTP server service listens. The default of 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases can help ease migration tasks among machines. If the FTP server service is listening on a virtual IP address managed by a standby control group with the self-balancing feature enabled, incoming control and data connections will always go to the active member of the standby control group.

property.hoverhelp: Enter the IP address to listen on for incoming FTP server traffic. The default value 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service listens on all IP addresses.
property.label: IP address

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Local TCP port for the FTP server

description.p: Enter the port that is monitored by the FTP Server service. This port is the port on which FTP control connections can be established. This port does not control the TCP port that is used for the data connections. If the FTP client uses the PASV command, data connections will use an arbitrary, unused TCP port. Defaults to 21. Valid range is 1 through 65535.

property.hoverhelp: Enter the port number to listen on for incoming FTP server traffic. Specify a number in the range of 1 - 65535. The default value is 21.
property.label: Port

property.name: FilesystemType
property.summary: The type of filesystem the FTP server will present

description.p: Select the file system type that is presented by the FTP server.

ul.li: If Virtual Ephemeral or Virtual Persistent is chosen, the client can write files to all directories. These files are shown in directory listings but cannot be retrieved. For file system responses, the responses are shown and can be retrieved, renamed, and deleted by the client.
If Transparent is chosen, the file system shows the contents of the equivalent path of the server on the back-end of the Multi-Protocol Gateway with which this FTP server is associated.

description.p: This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: PersistentFilesystemTimeout
property.summary: Controls how long a Virtual Persistent file system with no active connections is retained
property.description: Enter the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all FTP control connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. All of the response files that were not deleted by the FTP client are deleted from their storage area. Default to 600 (10 minutes). Valid range is 1 to 43,200 seconds (12 hours).

property.name: VirtualDirectories
property.summary: Create directory in virtual file system of FTP server
property.description: In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this FTP server. The FTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created. Its response directory is always the root directory.

property.name: DefaultDirectory
property.summary: Default for current working directory
property.description: Enter the initial working directory on the FTP server (after users connect and authenticate). When using a virtual file system and the working directory is not the root directory, the specified directory must be one of the configured virtual directories. The default is the root directory (/).

property.name: MaxFilenameLength
property.summary: Maximum length of a file name on the server
property.description: Enter the maximum file name length on the FTP server. Defaults to 256 characters. Valid range is 1 through 4000.

property.name: ACL
property.description: Select an Access Control List to apply. The ACL allows or denies access to the FTP server based on the IP address of the FTP client. When attached to a server, the default for an ACL is to deny all access. To deny access to only select IP addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0). Then, create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.name: RequireTLS
property.summary: Control whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption

description.p:
Specify whether FTP control connections require explicit TLS encryption. If required, the following rules apply:
The FTP client must use the FTP AUTH TLS command before any other command.
You must specify an SSL profile to secure connections.
This property does not control encryption of data transfers.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.summary: The SSL proxy profile is deprecated. Use an SSL server profile or SSL SNI server profile.
property.description: The SSL proxy profile references the required cryptographic configurations for the secure connection.

property.name: PasswordAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA policy for validating user name and password

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of user names and passwords provided to the FTP server by the client with the USER and PASS commands. If the authentication succeeds, the FTP client may use all the features of the FTP server. If the authentication fails, a 530 error is returned, and the user can attempt to authenticate again. Without this AAA Policy configured, any user name and password will be accepted.

property.name: CertificateAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA Policy for determining whether password is required

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform secondary authentication of the information provided in the TLS/SSL certificate provided during TLS negotiation after the AUTH TLS command to the FTP server. Primary authentication is done by the SSL Profile, it can completely reject a certificate. This authentication stage controls whether an FTP password will be demanded or not. If the result of this authentication succeeds, the FTP client will only have to use the USER command to login after the AUTH TLS. If this authentication fails, the FTP client will have to use both the USER and PASS commands to complete the login process. If no Certificate AAA Policy is configured, USER and PASS will always be required. If the AUTH TLS command is not used by the FTP client, USER and PASS will always be required.

property.name: AllowCCC
property.summary: Control use of CCC command

description.p: Specify whether the FTP CCC command can be used to turn off TLS encryption of the FTP control connection after user authentication. If allowed, the CCC command can be used to turn off encryption after authentication. Turning off encryption is necessary when the FTP control connection crosses a firewall or NAT device that needs to sniff the control connection. Turning off encryption eliminates the secrecy of the files being transferred and allows TCP packets injection attacks.

property.name: Passive
property.summary: Control use of passive mode
property.description: Control use of the FTP PASV and EPSV commands by the FTP client, as an alternative to the PORT and EPRT commands. The default is to allow PORT, EPRT, PASV, and EPSV. Other settings either require PASV or EPSV, or require PORT or EPRT. If an acceptable PORT, EPRT, PASV, or EPSV command is not received, the STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, and NLST data transfer commands will fail. (This FTP server will never attempt to connect to the deprecated default FTP data port at TCP port 20.)

property.name: UsePasvPortRange
property.display: Limit Port Range for Passive Connections
property.summary: Enable using a limited range of TCP port numbers for Passive connections.

description.p: When enabled, when a PASV or EPSV command is received from the FTP client, instead of selecting any free listening TCP port in the range 1024 to 65534, allow configuration of a restricted port range. This may be used when a firewall wants to allow incoming FTP data connections only on a limited range of ports, particularly when it cannot "sniff" the FTP control connection.

Note that the size of the range specified limits how many FTP clients can be in the state between receiving the 227 response code to the PASV or EPSV command, and establishing the FTP data TCP connection. Pressure on this limited resource can be controlled by adjusting the passive data connection idle timeout.

While it is perfectly legal to configure multiple FTP servers on the same system to use the same (or overlapping) passive port ranges, realize that they are contending for a common resource in the TCP implementation.

However, it is not wise to use a port range that overlaps with other services (HTTP servers, etc.) that are configured on the system. There is no configuration checking for such conflicts, and other configured services will allocate the ports first, and they will not be available for the FTP server. (The FTP server allocates these listing ports dynamically.)

property.name: PasvMinPort
property.summary: Lowest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the lowest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not greater than Maximum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvMaxPort
property.summary: Highest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the highest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not less than Minimum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvIdleTimeOut
property.summary: Idle timeout for a passive data connection

description.p: Specifies the number of seconds that the server waits for a client to establish a passive connection. Use an integer in the range of 5 through 300. The default is 60.

This setting controls the amount of time in seconds between when the FTP server issues code 227 (Entering Passive Mode) in response to the PASV or EPSV command from the FTP client and when the FTP client must establish a TCP data connection to the listening port and issue a data transfer command.

ul.li: If the data connection is not established within the timeout period, the listening port will be closed. If a data transfer command is issued after the port is closed, the command fails with code 425 and the Failed to open data connection message.

If the data connection is established but no data transfer command is issued within the timeout period, the TCP data connection will be closed. Any data transfer command after the timeout will be treated as if the PASV or EPSV command was never issued. The command fails with code 425 and the Require PASV or PORT command first message.

property.name: DisablePASVIPCheck
property.display: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check
property.summary: Disable Passive Data Connection (PASV) IP Security Check

description.p: This option will disable the IP security check that is done when processing the FTP PASV command. The check verifies that the IP address of the client connecting to the data connection is the same as the one that established the control connection.

The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server. Turn the option on if there is a specific reason the incoming connection will not be coming from the same client as the control connection (i.e. from a load balancer).
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: DisablePORTIPCheck
property.display: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check
property.summary: Disable Active Data Connection (PORT) IP Security Check

description.p: This option will disable the IP security check that verifies that outgoing data connections can only connect to the client.
The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server.
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: UseAlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Use Alternate PASV IP Address

description.p: When on, this option will enable the ability to override the IP address that is presented to the FTP client when the server is in passive mode.
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: AlternatePASVAddr
property.summary: Alternate PASV IP Address

description.p: The numeric IP address that will be returned to the FTP client in response to a PASV command. This does not change the IP address that the FTP server will listen on, which is always the IP address that the FTP data connection was made to. This is used in certain situations when the FTP server is behind a firewall that is not FTP-aware.

property.name: AllowLISTCmd
property.summary: Enable LIST command support

description.p: When on, the server will make a distinction between the LIST and NLST commands. When off, the server will always respond with an NLST when requesting a file listing.
The default value for this option is off
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: AllowDELECmd
property.summary: Enable DELE (delete) support

description.p: When on, allows the DELE (delete) command to be passed to the FTP back-end server. This is only valid in Transparent Filesystem type.
The default value for this option is off
This configuration property is only supported by the FTP Server front-side protocol handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: DataEncryption
property.summary: Control use of data encryption for file transfers
property.description: Select the use of encryption for data connections (file transfers). Data encryption is controlled by the FTP PROT P command.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Control use of MODE Z command to compress data transfer

description.p: Specify whether the FTP client can use FTP MODE Z compression. After enabling FTP compression, the FTP client can use the zlib method to compress data transfers.

property.name: AllowSTOU
property.summary: Control use of STOU command for unique file names

description.p: Specify whether the FTP client can use the FTP STOU command. When enabled, the FTP server generates a unique file name for each transferred file.

property.name: UniqueFilenamePrefix
property.summary: Prefix of all unique filenames generated by STOU

description.p: Enter the prefix (leading characters) for file names that are generated when using the FTP STOU command. When defining the prefix, the directory separator (/) is not allowed. The default is to not add a prefix, which is an empty string.
Note: The software adds a numeric suffix.

property.name: AllowREST
property.summary: Control use of the REST command for interrupted file transfers

description.p: Controls whether the FTP client can use the FTP REST command to continue the transfer of a file after an interruption in the data transfer. This is supported in the BSD stream style described in draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt. (The MODE B style that is described in RFC 959 is not supported.) The FTP server must be configured with a virtual persistent file system.

For written files, the server will delay the actual processing until a timeout expires or until the next FTP command other than a SIZE or REST command. This processing allows the FTP client can return and resume to the transfer using the SIZE, REST, and STOR commands. The argument to the REST command must be the same as the byte count returned by the SIZE command.
Note: The response code to all STOR commands on this server will always be 226. The response codes does not reflect the success of the transaction.
This capability is also supported for reading the response files, if the server is configured for a Response Type of Virtual Filesystem.
Note: The generation of response files are delayed until the transaction is completed.

property.name: RestartTimeout
property.summary: Time that the STOR command waits for a restart

description.p: When restart (REST) is enabled, the number of seconds that the FTP client has to reconnect to the server and use the SIZE, REST, and STOR commands to continue an interrupted file transfer. If this period of time elapses, the data that was received to this point on the TCP data connection will be passed to the Multi-Protocol Gateway. This timeout is canceled if another command (other than SIZE or REST) is received on the FTP control connection.

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Inactivity limit on FTP control connection
property.description: Enter the number of seconds that the FTP control connection can be idle. After the specified duration elapses, the FTP server closes the control connection. Defaults to 0, which disables the timeout.

property.name: ResponseType
property.summary: How to make response available to FTP client
property.description: Select how to make response files available for gateway transactions started by an FTP STOR or SOUT operation.

property.name: ResponseStorage
property.summary: Where to store response files
property.description: Select where response files are stored.

property.name: TemporaryStorageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of temporary file system
property.description: Enter in megabytes the maximum size for the temporary file system size. Defaults to 32 MB. Valid range is 1 MB through 2048 MB.

property.name: ResponseNFSMount
property.summary: NFS mount to store response files in

description.p: When Response Type is Virtual File System and Response Storage is NFS, select an NFS static mount to apply. Each response file will have a unique file name in the NFS directory. The name of the response file is not related to the file name that the virtual file system presents to the FTP client. Generally, this NFS directory is not made available through the FTP server. This directory should not be used for any other purpose.

property.name: ResponseSuffix
property.summary: URL file name suffix to response file
property.description: When the response type is a virtual file system, enter the suffix to add when generating response files. The directory separator (/) is not allowed. If the response type is a virtual file system and the FTP client is writing in virtual directories that do not have a response directory or if the response directory is the same as the virtual directory, this value must have a non-empty value. If empty, the response would try to overwrite the request, which is not allowed. Defaults to an empty string.

property.name: SSLServerConfigType
property.summary: Set the SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance

description.p: The SSL profile type to secure connections between clients and the appliance. If an SSL profile is assigned, the FTP AUTH TLS server command will be enabled, and the client will be able to start SSL/TLS encryption of the FTP control connection.

The chosen SSL profile controls the SSL/TLS credentials that the FTP server will present to the client after the AUTH TLS command, and how the SSL/TLS credentials presented by the client will be evaluated.

property.name: SSLServer
property.summary: Set the SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

property.name: SSLSNIServer
property.summary: Set the SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance
property.description: The SSL SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the appliance.

description.p: The FTP Server Front Side Handler provides an FTP server that can be used to submit files for processing by the system. Each file that is written results in one transaction.
There can be multiple FTP servers, but only one server can listen on the default port 21 on a given IP address. There can be multiple simultaneous connections from FTP clients to the same FTP server.

ul.li: The 226 FTP response code at the end of an FTP STOR or STOU command is conditional on successful completion of the internal steps and backside operation of the transaction.
Changes in the configuration affect only new connections to this FTP server. Existing connections continue to use their current configuration until they disconnect.

object.name: HTTPSourceProtocolHandler

property.name: UserSummary
property.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
property.description: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: Enter the IP address or host alias on which the HTTP handler listens.
property.description: The address on which the HTTP handler listens. The default value indicates that the handler listens on all IPv4 addresses.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the IP address or host alias on which the HTTP handler listens. The default value indicates that the handler listens on all IPv4 addresses.
property.label: IP address

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Enter the port on which the HTTPS handler listens.
property.description: The port on which the HTTP handler listens. The default value is 80.
property.hoverhelp: Enter the port on which the HTTP handler listens. The default value is 80.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.summary: Set the HTTP version for the client side connection.
property.description: The HTTP version for the client side connection. The default value is HTTP 1.1. For the HTTP/2 protocol, requests and responses are always HTTP/2. When HTTP/2, this setting is ignored.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Set the methods and versions to allow for incoming requests.
property.description: The methods and versions to allow for incoming requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Indicate whether to negotiate persistent client side connections.
property.description: Whether to negotiate persistent client side connections. The HTTP/2 protocol controls persistent connections and reuse. Therefore, these settings are ignored.

property.name: MaxPersistentConnectionsReuse
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of times a persistent client side connection is reused.
property.description: The maximum number of times a persistent client side connection is reused. When the maximum reuse count is reached, an explicit HTTP Connection: close header is sent in the response, and the TCP connection is closed. The default value is 0, which means unlimited reuse.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Indicate whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.

description.p: Whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.
If enabled, the DataPower service uses GZIP to compress HTTP transmissions when the Accept-Encoding HTTP header indicates that compressed documents can be processed.
The Transfer-Encoding HTTP header indicates compression.

property.name: AllowWebSocketUpgrade
property.summary: Indicate whether to allow WebSocket upgrade requests from clients.
property.description: Whether to allow WebSocket upgrade requests from clients. This request is to switch the existing connection to use the WebSocket protocol. WebSocket upgrade requests require that the handler allows GET methods.

property.name: WebSocketIdleTimeout
property.summary: Enter the maximum idle time for client connections.
property.description: The maximum idle time for client connections. This timer monitors the idle time in the data transfer process. When the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The default value is 0, which indicates that the timer is disabled.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: Enter the length of the longest incoming URL to accept.
property.description: The length of the longest incoming URL to accept. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier. Enter a value in the range 1 - 128000. The default value is 16384.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Enter the maximum aggregate length of HTTP headers to allow.
property.description: The maximum aggregate length of HTTP headers to allow. Enter a value in the range 5 - 128000. The default value is 128000.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.summary: Enter the maximum number of headers to allow in client requests.
property.description: The maximum number of headers to allow in client requests. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.summary: Enter the maximum length of a header name to allow in client requests.
property.description: The maximum length of a header name to allow in client requests. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting sets the maximum length of the name portion of a header. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.summary: Enter the maximum length of a header value to allow in client requests.
property.description: The maximum length of a header value to allow in client requests. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting sets the maximum length of the value portion of a header. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
